[{'document_title': 'The Consul for the Bight of Biafra', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are authorized to announce that the Consulate for the Bights, vacant by the death of the late Consul Hartley, has been offered by Her Majesty’s Government to Mr. David Hopkins, now Consul at Loanda. In this appointment the Earl of Derby has fulfilled at the same time the hopes and desires of the British merchants trading with the Oil River, and of the natives of those rivers. Many of these in making known their desires, have expressed to us their confidence in the kindness, uprightness, and justice of Mr. Hopkins, who is well known among them. We believe, that in order to place some official restraint on the actions of agents and masters of vessels trading in the River Niger, the whole course of that river as far as Egga will be within the jurisdiction of Consul Hopkins.', 'last_edit_date': '1877-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1877#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.737, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger and Territories on the West Coast of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have been requested to publish the following correspondence:—

"Chamber of Commerce, Manchester, Nov. 2, 1883.

"My Lord,—In November last year this Chamber addressed to your lordship a memorial praying that the earnest endeavours of Her Majesty's Government might be directed towards promoting a friendly understanding with other European Governments in order that the sovereign and territorial rights of the natives of the Congo River, and of the adjacent territories on the West Coast of Africa, might be respected and maintained, and that there should be no interference on the part of any Power with the existing freedom of navigation and commerce.

"The attention of other European nations is now being devoted to the extension of commerce, and to the increasing importance, not only of the Congo, but also of the Niger and other rivers, which are the principal means of communication and of trade with the populous tribes in the centre of Africa, and there is reason to fear that they are seeking to annex territories, and also to secure such concessions from native rulers as may enable them to put a hindrance to that freedom of trade and navigation which has hitherto been enjoyed on the West Coast of Africa.

"Your lordship has recently been informed of certain proceedings of French officers on the Niger and the Bonny, and other rivers and places on the African coast, which call for the serious consideration of Her Majesty's Government. When it is remembered that the trade in most of these rivers has been mainly established and carried on by British merchants, and that it has been from Great Britain that the ruling chiefs have hitherto sought and obtained assistance, and also that British officers have for many years undertaken the responsibility of maintaining peace and order among them, Her Majesty's Government cannot be surprised that the proceedings of French officers above alluded to have caused considerable apprehension among the merchants.

"Although the influence which Great Britain has exercised in the Bight of Benin has been in a great measure only moral, it has benefited the trade, tended to promote progress among the natives, and increased their respect for the British Government, whilst securing the lives and property of European settlers. The interference of any other European Power with native rights cannot but tend to endanger the peace, and to hinder both civilization and the development of trade, and of friendly relations with these African tribes.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-11-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1883#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.738, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE ON THE WESTERN COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Some little time back, when the various rivers and territories of the different kings and chiefs in this part of the world were placed under British protection, the kings and chiefs of Brass peremptorily declined to sign any treaty of that nature unless they were granted certain privileges as to trading in the Niger—privileges which they asserted appertained to them both by prescription and right, and to have been forcibly taken away from them, and all their trading in that river stopped by the National African Company. As it was of importance to Great Britain, who had already secured the remainder of the Niger, to prevent this mouth of it falling into the hands of any foreign Power, the British Consul at that time promised he would do all that lay in his power in the matter, and a temporary treaty was, on this understanding, signed for a period of six months. Nothing, however, was done in the matter by the British authorities, and when this treaty expired in July of last year no consular authority existed in any part of this coast, so that no steps were then taken either to renew it or to get a permanent one signed. However, Mr. Consul Hewett returned to the West Coast of Africa about six months ago, armed with instructions from Her Majesty's Government to take the necessary steps to place the Brass River and the territory in connexion therewith under British protection, and he accordingly made a preliminary visit here in September to hold a "palaver" with the kings and chiefs on the subject. On that occasion those personages did not put in an appearance, but the Consul informed them in writing that he would shortly return to negotiate a treaty with them, and that it was the opinion of the British Government that the principles of free trade should be carried out, and that the people of Brass were at liberty to trade wherever they chose. This message by no means satisfied the chiefs of this river, as the National African Company took care that they should not trade in any of the waters under its jurisdiction. Shortly afterwards, the Consul received a message to the effect that they did not intend to part with their country unless they obtained further privileges. Hence the recent visit of the Consul. Shortly afterwards the Consul summoned them to a "palaver" on board the *Watchful*—a summons which they neither answered nor obeyed. Thereupon, an officer was despatched with an ultimatum from the Consul, intimating that, if they did not obey his summons within twenty-four hours, the matter would be placed in the hands of the naval officer to take steps to enforce it. The chiefs thereupon obeyed the summons and appeared on board the *Watchful*, so as to avoid the consequences of refusal. They refused to agree to one article of the treaty—that which granted permission for the ministers of all religious denominations to reside in their territory, and erect places of worship therein.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.751, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Proposed Charter of the African Association', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'on a trading company for administering the whole of the country through which the Niger flows, and now great efforts were being made by the African Association Limited to obtain by Royal Charter similar powers over the palm oil river district—namely, Benin, Toreados, Brass, New Calabar, Bonny, Opobo, and Old Calabar. Since the charter was granted to the Niger Company several of his customers who had been connected with the Niger trade had written to him to say that it was impossible for anyone but the Niger Company themselves to do business, and so they were obliged to give up trading on that river. Consequently he took it upon himself to write to the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, drawing attention to this fact and begging his lordship to take the matter in hand, and see that common fairness was done to all who were anxious to trade in the Niger River. In his own opinion justice would never be done to the natives and the merchants until the administrative department was altogether separated from the trade and from those engaged in trade. He would be very sorry to see such powers as had been given to the Niger Company conferred upon the African Association, because it was quite obvious the interests of the native traders and producers were not likely to be fairly dealt with where all questions in dispute had to be settled by the officers of a trading corporation interested in making the utmost profit for their employers. There was a large body of native traders and producers in the oil district, increasing in number and importance every year. If a monopoly were created, such as was being sought for, the native traders and producers would have only one large customer, who would buy their produce on his own terms. The revenue to be derived from the district, if administered by the government of a Crown colony or annexed to the colony of Lagos, would pay its administrative expenses, the trade of the palm oil rivers district being the most valuable of the West Coast of Africa. The Lagos colony itself, with a trade about a third the volume of that of the oil rivers, showed in ten years a surplus revenue of £65,000. In the memorial the inhabitants of Lagos said: "The rivers comprising the deltas of the Bights of Benin and Biafra form a belt of outlets to a vast produce-yielding interior, rich with natural resources and teeming with hundreds of thousands of Africans who are ready and willing on favourable terms to grant admission to their countries, and to barter their produce and manufacturers for European goods and merchandise. To develop and build up this great commerce, and to Christianise and civilise the native population is the problem which her Majesty's Government is now called upon to solve. We have no hesitation in asserting that it can only be done by free, legitimate, and unfettered commerce, fostered and protected directly by her Majesty's Government, for there can be no two opinions as to the necessity for free and unfettered competition in the development of the commercial resources of a new and dormant country, and the results to commerce and civilisation in the littoral possessions of her Majesty on this coast abundantly testify as to what may be obtained under proper conditions; and Lagos could be cited as an instance in which the above influences have, within a very few years, transformed it from a barbarous and unimportant place into a progressive civilised colony, with a total export and import trade of £906,811, and a revenue of £58,000 per annum. We unhesitatingly assert that it is impossible for these results to be achieved by a trading company invested with administrative powers; for it would naturally, in its own interest, pursue a policy advantageous to itself, and which could have no other tendency than to stagnate the thrift and industry necessary to the healthy development of a country and its resources." The administrative department of the colony of Lagos had worked very well for all concerned, and it seemed convenient to annex the oil rivers first to that colony. The district extended from 300 to 400 miles on the coast of Africa, between the German boundary and the Cameroons, and the eastern boundary of the British Crown colony of Lagos, and inland to the territories of the Niger Company, and over this area the African Association wished to have the monopoly of trade. The country was densely populated. This district was at present under Imperial protection and the jurisdiction of consular courts, which was better than under the administration of a company formed for private gain. It would be infinitely better under administration as a Crown colony, and he trusted that a Crown colony would be established in connexion with apart from the colony of Lagos.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1890#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.731, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Oil Rivers District', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The African Steamship Company's royal mail steamer Niger, which has recently arrived in the Mersey from the West Coast, brings information that on the 23rd March Consul Johnstone was at Buguma, having gone specially thither in H.M.S. Bramble to settle some trade disputes. Most of the cases were amicably settled, but some of the chiefs did not turn up, although they had received timely notice of the meeting. This was regarded as contempt of court, and as a result, the Consul proceeded in the Bramble to Bakana, and took as prisoners the Chiefs Will Braid and India Yellow. The chiefs were left in charge of the Consul's representative at Buguma. It was understood that Will Braid had not paid some penalty imposed on him, and that the Consul had taken the step to secure it.

Previous to the Consul visiting Buguma he went to Benin and held a great palaver at the factory of Messrs. Stuart & Douglas. This was for the purpose of officially declaring the British protectorate over the place, and of informing the great Chief Nanna what the conditions were. All the agents were present, and Chief Nanna sat on the Consul's right. The Consul explained that he had established a new British court, which would supersede the old Court of Equity. Rules would be sent by the Consul from Old Calabar, and these would have to be hung up. As in the cases of Bonny and the other rivers, the court was to have jurisdiction in both civil and criminal cases, and when the amount exceeded £5 an appeal would lie to the Consul. "Comey," or trade tribute, was abolished, and in its place an export duty of 1s. 6d. per ton would be charged on palm oil and 6d. on kernels. When collected, one-half would be divided amongst the Governor (Nanna) and his chiefs, the balance to go towards maintaining peace on the river. The "trust" customs were to be abolished, and if the natives were found mixing shells with kernels or water with the palm oil they would be fined. Consul Johnstone said he was pleased with Nanna's conduct, particularly in sending the case of Mr. Reece, the British trader, to be dealt with by the Consul, and that he would tell Her Majesty the Queen of his conduct. Nanna seemed pleased with the prospect of being under Queen Victoria. The other native rulers are reported to be also similarly pleased with the idea of being under English rule.

When the Niger left Bonny it was understood that H.M.S. Bramble was going to take Consul Johnstone to Opobo, in order that he might adjust matters there, particularly as regarded the white men going to the native markets, and also to settle the claims which the merchants were making for the damage received by them through their factories being burned down or otherwise destroyed by the natives some time ago.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.738, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger Trouble', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At a recent meeting of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, the following resolution was carried: "That the members of the African Trade Section are of opinion that the charter granted to the Royal Niger Company, Limited, constitutes a virtual monopoly of the trade of the Niger district, thereby affecting prejudicially British interests in the adjoining rivers. The charter was obtained on the statement that all other European interests in that district had been bought up, which is not the case, and the members of the section are therefore of opinion that the charter should be revoked." It was further resolved that the Council of the Chamber should be asked to adopt the resolution and forward copies of it to certain members of the Government, members of Parliament, and Chambers of Commerce.

A letter from the Colonial Office relating to the administration of the Gold Coast was read. In it Sir H. Holland stated that the Government had consented that the Sefwhi country should on certain conditions be included in the British Protectorate, and he trusted that this action, together with the appointment of Captain Lonsdale as a Commissioner to visit the native tribes, will conduce to a reopening of the roads and an improvement and development of trade.

The *Liverpool Courier* has published the correspondence between Mr. W. F. Lawrence, M.P. for the Abercornby Division, and the Foreign Office on this burning subject.

In a subsequent issue of the *Courier*, a correspondent, signing himself "African Merchant," points out that "one passage in the Foreign Office letter of 27th January last is deserving of special attention—viz., a return to the old system is 'impracticable, even if it were desirable.' Such a declaration is astounding, and an outrage upon common sense. What are the facts? A company not long in existence has been granted sovereign rights and taxing powers over the imports and exports of from five to eight millions of people, and no company trading for its own benefit can exercise such powers in an impartial manner. Powers such as these can only be properly used by an independently-organized body, altogether unconnected with trade. Probably the Government having negotiated treaties with countries up the Niger, were glad to transfer their responsibility to the first who asked for it. Nominally there was to be no monopoly, but practically the greater number of traders are entirely debarred from doing business, and instead of there being free trade, open to all comers, the trade is absolutely shut up. Civilization is not promoted, but thrown back for an indefinite period of time.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1887#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.729, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COMMERCIAL COMPANIES FOR AFRICAN TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Niger and the Chadda—those important rivers of Africa—will now really be opened—will now be regularly and persistently traded in. This great end has been secured by the establishment of the Company of African Merchants, Limited (see advertisement, first page). With a strong mercantile and monied direction, this company took a firm stand at once. It absorbed the intended Niger and Chadda Company, lately advertised in our columns. The contemplated directors of the latter had only come forward with a view of securing for Great Britain the riches of the Niger countries, and for those countries that agricultural and commercial development of their resources which promises to make them rich and civilized, and to bring great advantages to England. For years past our heart has been fixed upon an adequate commercial effort in the River Niger. To see this great highway of Central Africa, this promising Mississippi of Africa, abandoned, or merely tinkered in by insufficient efforts, was more than we could patiently bear. We know—we consider it to be established beyond dispute—that, in addition to her other great resources, the Niger could, if proper means be employed, give within a few years its 100,000 bales of cotton a-year to Lancashire and the other northern manufacturing districts. Let it once give 100,000 bales a-year, and there will be nothing to prevent its furnishing later a million bales.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-07-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1863#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.73, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Liverpool and the African Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A special meeting of the Committee of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce was held on Nov. 10, under the chairmanship of Mr. Alfred L. Jones.

**Future Government of Nigeria, &c.**

The following letter, addressed by the Manchester Chamber to the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, was read:—

"Manchester Chamber of Commerce, Oct. 18, 1897.

"My Lord,—The Board of Directors of this Chamber considers the present an opportune occasion for addressing you on the subject of the government of the region adjacent to the River Niger, now directly or indirectly under British rule, with a view to suggesting measures for putting an end to the dangerous condition of affairs which at present exists in the Niger delta—a condition which, in the opinion of the Board, may spread to other districts if the existing customs and other difficulties be not speedily settled. The Board is convinced that the time has now arrived when her Majesty's Government may advantageously take into consideration the subject of the better administration of these regions. I am instructed respectfully to state that after full examination of the subject the Board has been led to the conclusion that the union of the Royal Niger Company's territory, the Niger Coast Protectorate, and Lagos in one colony under the control of the Colonial Office would afford the surest basis for the removal of these difficulties. The advantages offered by this arrangement are that the present Customs and boundary troubles would be done away with, that complications with foreign Powers would be minimised, and that great economies would be rendered possible in the cost of administration. Should, however, her Majesty's Government find it impracticable to bring about such an amalgamation at present, the Board desires to urge that whatever may be done in the meantime, falling short of this, should be considered to be of a temporary nature, having in view the ultimate consolidation of these territories under one Government. In any case the Board is of opinion that as an interim step the present boundary between Nigeria and the Niger Coast Protectorate should be abolished, the interior customs ports removed, and the two districts placed under the administration of the Colonial Office, or that some other arrangement should be made withdrawing the administrative powers of the Royal Niger Company, equitable compensation being paid to the Company for the large sums of money spent and the great services rendered by it in preserving to the British flag this large and populous tract of Africa.

"If neither of these courses should be thought desirable, it appears absolutely necessary that a Custom's Union, to which the three administrations should be parties, should be established with as little delay as possible, with a view to the removal of the difficulties already referred to.—I have, &c.,

(Signed) **Elijah Helm, Sec.**', 'last_edit_date': '1897-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1897#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.735, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH TRADE IN THE NIGER REGION', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Whatever may be the result of the Conference at Berlin, one important advantage will have been gained—viz., the opening of the eyes of Great Britain to the unassisted part that she has played during the past fifty years in the development of Central Africa north of the equator, and to her rights and duty to continue to act as the protector of the Lower Niger and Binue rivers, which, with their important tributaries, form one system which I will designate as the Niger-Binue. This term is in contradistinction to the Upper Niger, from Timbuctoo to the sources, which runs for a distance of 1,000 miles at the back of the French colony of Senegal, and which has been visited by several French exploring parties, though as yet no European trade has been opened there. Nor, indeed, can such trade be carried on profitably until the completion of the railway connecting the waterways of the Senegal and the Upper Niger. Between the latter and the Niger-Binue lies the long stretch of the Middle Niger, from Timbuctoo to Boussa; nature thus interposing a barrier of 800 miles between the Upper Niger basin, which will probably fall to France, and the Niger-Binue basin, which is already occupied by Great Britain. The Niger-Binue was unknown to Europe fifty-five years ago. The wildest theories were held as to the ultimate destination of the Niger—some geographers holding that it was absorbed by an inland sea, others that it fell into the Nile, others that it joined the Congo. The English traveller, John Lander, in 1831 solved the problem by starting from Badagry, and travelling northwards till he reached the Niger, near Boussa, where are the lowest rapids, and where commences the Niger-Binue system. He followed the river down 600 miles to the sea. Immediately on his return home, in 1832, his great discovery was turned to account by some Liverpool merchants, who despatched two steamers to nearly the highest navigable point on the Niger, and to Dagbo on the Binue. Numerous private expeditions from this country followed in the years 1834 to 1864, the most notable event being the formation in 1852 of the African Steamship Company, which established a line to Lokoga at the confluence of the Niger and Binue, 300 miles from the sea. Meanwhile the British Government had made efforts to open up both branches, and to lay down charts. Under an impulse given by Prince Consort, Parliament voted over £50,000 for the expedition of Her Majesty’s ships Albert, Wilberforce, and Soudan, during which the Government obtained the cession of a large tract of country about the confluence at Lokoga, where the British flag flies to this day. Another important expedition was that of 1854-5, during which were laid down most careful charts of the Binue for some hundreds of miles. In 1857 Parliament voted a five years' subsidy, averaging £7,000 a year, to Mr. Macgregor Laird, to assist him in developing trade in these rivers, and it was expressly stated on that occasion that immediate results could not be expected, but that posterity would reap the benefit. In a letter dated the 29th April, 1864, Earl Russell stated that he was willing to recommend a further subsidy of £6,000 for the same object. The proposal fell through—indeed, was rendered unnecessary by the springing up of British trade, which has lasted to the present day.", 'last_edit_date': '1884-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1884#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.737, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE GOVERNMENT OF THE OIL RIVERS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Considering how unsatisfactory is the present administration of this district, so far as concerns what is intended to be the protection of British interests, by means of a consular establishment at Old Calabar, we trust that her Majesty's Government will speedily modify this arrangement. We desire, however, to record our earnest protest against the proposal which, as we understand, is now being urged on her Majesty's Government for the transfer of control over the district, under a charter similar to that possessed by the Royal Niger Company, to a private corporation of merchants.

We do not here offer any remarks on the policy which led to the constitution of the Royal Niger Company, or on the mode in which it has thus far exercised its powers. But we feel very strongly that, whatever warrant there may have been for the organisation of that Company, whose object is to carry on trade with the tribes and communities in the interior, with whom it has established treaty relations, and to utilise the resources of the territories of which it has acquired possession, there is no warrant for assigning to private speculators similar authority over the coasts between the Benin and Old Calabar rivers, and on both sides of the principal mouth of the Niger. Through this mouth the Royal Niger Company has access by water to...

the vast and in many parts salubrious and fertile regions owned or regulated by it, whereas in the Oil Rivers District there are but few localities fit for European settlement or suitable for any industrial operations requiring such large outlay of capital and other costly enterprise as it may be proper to leave in private hands.

At no time can it be expected that the Oil Rivers District will prove valuable or attractive to Europeans, except as regards the towns and trading depôts established on the coast, and the commodities brought thither by natives and thence conveyed to foreign countries. Its ports may and should become far more prosperous marts than they now are; but, so far as white men are concerned, it can never be much more than a resort for merchants who will look to the natives for a supply of the articles they desire to obtain. The business which is already established here, and which is capable of great expansion under wholesome direction and restraint, is, we submit, especially of a sort that, if carried on by British enterprise, should not be withdrawn from the supervision of the British Government. A firmer and more just administration than it is conceivable that any association of merchants would be able to exercise is required, not only to prevent the dangers attending the setting up of an unfair monopoly by such an association against other traders, but yet more to protect the natives from tyranny, extortion and degradation.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.73, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "THE ROYAL NIGER COMPANY'S TERRITORIES", 'section_title': '', 'content': "My Lord,—I am directed to say, that the letter addressed to this Chamber by the Foreign Office on the 2nd February last on the above-named subject has been reported upon by the committee of the African Trade Section, to whose consideration it had been referred. A very great interest has long been taken by this Chamber in the affairs of both the Niger and Oil Rivers districts, in which districts members of its African Trade Section have a large amount of capital at stake. When it became publicly known that a charter had been granted to the Royal Niger Company, the African Trade Section passed a resolution protesting against the charter on the ground that their large interests in the delta of the Niger, and their growing interest in the trade of the river itself, were likely to be seriously prejudiced by the powers bestowed upon the Company. It was felt as a grievance that this Chamber had not received any intimation of the intention of the Government to grant a trading company jurisdiction over countries discovered, redeemed from the export slave traffic, and generally brought under British influence by national efforts and expenditure, and wherein members of its African Trade Section had long traded, and were making efforts to extend their trade; that trade having, moreover, had a civilising influence upon the tribes of the delta. Your lordship will remember the very strenuous efforts made by this Chamber in the year 1890 to prevent the granting of a charter for the Oil Rivers district. The movement for such a charter doubtless arose, in part, out of the desire to preserve the commercial interests at the Oil Rivers from the complications and injuries resulting from the position and policy of the Royal Niger Company, but the granting of it would have secured to the applicants a monopoly of the trade of the Oil Rivers similar in character to that of the Niger trade already possessed by the Royal Niger Company. It has been the object of this Chamber to keep those countries of West Africa which have been acquired by national effort and expenditure open for all British traders, and it therefore rejoiced when the Government, acceding to its representations, resolved that the Oil Rivers districts should continue under direct Imperial control. The Chamber regrets to learn that her Majesty's Secretary of State, instead of limiting the administration of the Royal Niger Company to the main stream of the Niger, as the direct approach to the countries where its trade is situated, is about to sanction, or has sanctioned, the extension of the jurisdiction of the Company over one-fourth of the area of the Oil Rivers district, thereby consenting to the appropriation by the Company of districts which fed the trade of Benin and Brass, and to the separation of the Benin district from the Brass, Bonny, and Calabar districts. The description in the letter from the Foreign Office of the geographical features of the Wari district is applicable to the whole of the delta of the Niger, and whilst it is felt that, owing to the character of the delta, it will be impossible for the Company to exercise effective control over the waterways assigned to them, this Chamber views with great apprehension the attempts likely to be made to acquire a control, which will harass the merchants of the Oil Rivers and will probably lead to conflicts with the natives. The Chamber objects to the division of the Oil Rivers district for the following reasons, viz.: (1) That it is naturally one district; (2) that its waterways should not be under two separate and conflicting jurisdictions and fiscal systems; (3) that there should be no regulations in respect to its waterways calculated to obstruct free navigation of channels and creeks which are maintained by natural forces, and which, in the absence of the possibility of roads, are the highways of the district; (4) that the Wari districts were placed, by treaties, under the protection of the British Government prior to the making of any treaties by the Royal Niger Company, and that the British Consul recognised and enforced that condition by his action when the claims of the Company were first put forward; and the Chamber, moreover, in order to secure to the Oil Rivers Administration its proper sphere of development and its natural hinterground, respectfully submits that the Delta of the Niger should be placed under the jurisdiction of the Commissioner and Consul-General for the Oil River Protectorate. It is urged that this step will inflict no injustice upon the Company. The National African Company Limited, when petitioning for a charter, represented that they had purchased the business of all European traders in the basin of the River Niger. They, however, neither compensated the smaller traders of Lagos, Sierra Leone, and this country, who were striving together with the larger firms to develop the Niger trade, who up to the date of the charter enjoyed free trade on the river, and who strongly protested against the loss of that privilege, nor did the Company buy up any portion of the much greater interests of the merchants of Oil Rivers (including Wari), who are again injured by the proposed extension of the charter over the districts between the Nun and the Forcados rivers, wherein Benin and Brass merchants have long carried on a trade created by their capital and enterprise. This Chamber does not mistake the terms of the charter, and is not under the impression that any traders are excluded from the Company's markets otherwise than by the obligation to pay the exorbitant license fees and duties imposed by the Company, and by the regulations enforced against their competitors in trade. Monopoly is prohibited and differential treatment is forbidden by Article 14 of the Company's charter, but so long as the Company are allowed to claim as their private property the land on both banks of the river and continue to be both a governing and trading body, they will legislate and execute for their own special advantage in trade. The almost total extinction of rival trade to that of the Company in the Niger Protectorate, where formerly there was so much competition, is a proof that the unfair influence and policy of the Company have secured them a monopoly. The fact that the details of the revenue and expenditure of the Company are kept from the public, and that there is therefore no proof that the Company exact the licenses from their own agents which they impose upon the agents of other traders, or that they debit themselves with the duties which they levy upon others, leaves them open to the charge of trading under a preferential system favourable to their own interests. It is recommended that the boundary of the Royal Niger Company's territories be altered so as to restore to the Oil Rivers district the Delta of the Niger as far as Onitcha, Asaba remaining in the possession of the Company, and Onitcha being included in the Oil Rivers Protectorate, and that the rights of the Company in respect to the navigation of the river be guarded in the spirit of the free navigation clauses of the Act of Berlin, to which the Foreign Office refers.", 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-24', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1892#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.726, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Progress on the West African Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The African rivers situate in the Bight of Benin, commonly known as the Oil Rivers, have been placed under the protectorate of Great Britain. The protectorate, announced at Bonny, in December last, by Admiral Sir Walter Hunt Grubb, extends from the right bank of Benin river to the Rio del Rey, thus including Brass, New and Old Calabar, Bonny, Opobo, and other important trading stations.

Two series of considerations, the internal and external, have combined to render action imperative, and a retrospective view may not be uninstructive. Since the abolition of the export of slaves, these localities have been the sites of trading stations, palm oil being the chief article of export. The traders have been, with few exceptions, British, and the capitalists mostly Liverpool merchants. The natives allowed trading hulks to be anchored and commerce conducted on payment of fixed sums, known as "comey." Bonny, Brass, and Old Calabar are among the oldest of these trading ports, the native chiefs being also the native traders. They possessed numerous slaves who were sent with merchandise to the interior markets to collect oil, which was brought to the stations and sold to the whites. Among the Bonny chiefs was the father of Ja Ja, late King of Opobo; his son was brought up to the management of the business, and on his father's death he succeeded to his position. Of his enemies the most powerful was Oko Jumbo, who lost no opportunity to humiliate him. The Europeans could only let matters take their course; they regretted constant fighting of Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, but the relations between the Europeans and natives being strictly commercial, nothing could be done. Suffering reverses, Ja Ja was forced to fly with the remnant of his people after great slaughter at the hands of Oko Jumbo. He collected his scattered family, dependants, and slaves, and made his escape to the Opobo river. There Ja Ja found a place for his town, and established himself as King of Opobo.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.727, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE WEST AFRICAN CONFERENCE', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the sitting on Dec. 1, it was expected that the British claims to a protectorate of the Niger would be discussed, but this was left for a subsequent meeting. But it was understood upon good authority that no intervention with British rights on the Lower Niger was to be expected.

The following is the text (abridged) of the Declaration relative to freedom of trade in the basin of the Congo, as approved by the Conference:—

"I. The trade of all nations shall enjoy complete freedom—(1) in all the regions forming the basin of the Congo and its outlets, comprising the regions watered by the Congo and its affluents, including Lake Tanganyika with its eastern tributaries; (2) in the littoral of the Atlantic Ocean, extending from Sette Camma to the mouth of the Loge; (3) in the zone (of territory) stretching eastwards from the Congo basin to the Indian Ocean from the fifth degree of north latitude to the mouth of the Zambesi in the south, from which point the line of demarcation will ascend the Zambesi from its confluence with the Schire, and then follow the watershed between the affluents of Lake Nyassa and those of the Zambesi, till at last it reaches the watershed between the waters of the Zambesi and the Congo. It is expressly recognized that in extending the principle of free trade to this eastern zone the Powers only undertake engagements for themselves, and that in the territories belonging to an independent sovereign State this principle shall only be applicable in so far as it is approved by such State.

"II. All flags shall have access to the whole of the coastline above enumerated, and to the rivers there running into the sea, to all the waters of the Congo and its affluents, and all the ports on the banks of these waters, as well as to all canals which may in future be constructed with intent to unite the watercourses or lakes within the entire area of the territories described in Article I. They will engage in all sorts of transport, and carry on trade on the banks of lake and river, as well as boat traffic, on the same footing as the subjects (of the free trade territory) themselves.

"III. Wares imported into these regions, by lake or river, or overland, shall be subject to no other taxes than such as may be levied as fair compensation for expenditure in the interest of trade, and which for this reason must be equally borne by all. All levying of differential dues on vessels or commodities is forbidden.

"IV. The commodities imported into those regions shall remain free from import and transit dues. The Powers reserve to themselves to determine after the lapse of twenty years whether this freedom of import shall be retained or not.

"V. No Power which exercises sovereign rights in these regions shall be allowed to grant monopoly or favour of any kind in matters of trade. Foreigners shall enjoy protection of their persons and property, as well as the right of acquiring and transferring possessions.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1885#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.731, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Upon another page our readers will find the text of a letter which has been addressed by the members of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce to Lord Salisbury, as Foreign Secretary, upon the subject of the boundaries of the territories of the Royal Niger Company in the Oil Rivers Districts. As is perhaps only natural, the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce strongly protested against the extension of the authority of the Royal Niger Company over any portion of the Oil Rivers, and they point out that only two years ago the grant of a Royal Charter was refused to this very district. No doubt the presence of a large trading company, endued with special and exceptional powers, has a tendency to dwarf other commercial undertakings in the same district. But the Government are necessarily swayed by broader considerations than the advantage or disadvantage of certain individual traders. Their chief object is to provide for the administration of the particular district. The existence of chartered companies is only tolerable in uncivilised or semi-civilised countries, where the presence of a strong commercial interest may often enable the governing body to provide for the administration of the district without the great expense that would have to be incurred by the home Government if they attempted the direct administration themselves. The history of the development of India under the fostering rule of the Honourable East India Company proves the correctness of this theory, and to her Majesty's ministers it appears that the Royal Niger Company occupies an analogous position in its own district. The charter which was granted to the Niger Company some years ago is sufficiently careful in safeguarding the interests of others, and the success which has attended its administration of the district in question appears fully to justify an extension of its authority in the direction of the Oil Rivers. hh: British diplomatic efforts in West Africa, including the appointment of consuls and strategic missions, were aimed at maintaining influence, mediating conflicts, and strengthening trade relations in the region.
result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that British diplomatic efforts in West Africa were aimed at maintaining influence, mediating conflicts, and strengthening trade relations. The textbook highlights the appointment of consuls, such as John Beecroft in 1849, and the establishment of Courts of Equity as means for Britain to exert influence and control over local judicial systems, thereby diminishing the power of local rulers. Consuls played a key role in mediating peace treaties, like those between Bonny and Elem Kalahari, and employed gunboat diplomacy to secure favorable conditions for British traders. The signing of treaties of protection with local chiefs often included clauses for ending the slave trade and promoting legitimate trade, illustrating Britain's strategy to secure trade advantages and political influence. However, resistance, such as the removal of Jaja of Opobo for opposing British trade interests, indicates that these efforts were not always successful or welcomed. Similarly, The African Times articles discuss the appointment of consuls like Consul Livingston, who mediated between rival chiefs in the Bonny River region, underscoring Britain's role in conflict resolution. Strategic missions, such as Major Festing's mission to Almami Samory, aimed to cultivate friendly relations and maintain British influence. The articles emphasize the importance of British consular authority for successful mediation and peace maintenance, aligning with the claim of diplomatic efforts to bolster trade relations. They also highlight Britain's interest in expanding trade and influence, noting the significance of West African colonies for British commerce and the need for effective administration and infrastructure. Challenges, such as competition from other European powers and governance issues, add complexity to the claim. Overall, both sources provide a nuanced view that largely supports the claim while acknowledging the difficulties faced by British diplomatic efforts in the region.

[{'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Niger delta > The eastern delta', 'content': "The decision to abolish the slave trade by Britain in 1807 was an important factor for change. These British activities on the coast gradually eroded the power of the local rulers, especially when the consuls and naval officers assisted the British traders to set up their own judicial systems over and above the law of the local states, the so-called Courts of Equity, composed mainly of British traders with the participation of a few local House Heads or chiefs. The inter-state wars did not weaken the resolve of each of the states to keep European traders from encroaching on their spheres of trade or in the maintenance of their sovereignty. Both British and French abolitionist missions from different parts of the Lower Guinea coast commonly had to visit Dahomey kings at Agbome in the first half of the century. Similarly, British peace› makers involved in resolving aspects of nineteenth-century Yoruba warfare had to travel virtually throughout the length and breadth of the culture area.

The appointment in 1849 of John Beecroft as British Consul for the Bights of Benin and Bonny (formerly Biafra) signalled the dawn of a new era. British interests came to be specifically protected visà-vis the interest of other European nationals; British interests were also advanced against those of Africans. We have already drawn attention to the penetration of the Benin kingdom from the Niger delta and the resultant whittling down of Benin's trading hinterland to the extent of the eventual abandonment of Ughoton, Benin's traditional port. Further west, suspicion of British political intentions grew in 1851 when Lagos was bombarded by the anti-slave trade squadron.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.734, 'probability_score': 0.052, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in West Africa, 1880-1914', 'section_title': 'Conquest and reaction in British West Africa, 1880-1900 > Southern Nigeria', 'content': "While the Yoruba, by and large, chose the strategy of submission, the rulers of the kingdom of Benin and some of the rulers of the states of the Niger Delta chose that of confrontation. This, of course, would not be tolerated in that age, and using the killing of the British acting consul-general and five other Englishmen on their way to Benin as an excuse, the British launched a punitive expedition of 1500 men against Benin in 1897. Though the Oba himself would have liked to submit, a majority of his chiefs raised an army to beat back the invasion. They were, however, defeated and the capital was looted of its precious bronze treasures and then burnt. 48 In the Niger Delta, as in many other areas of Nigeria, the British had signed treaties of protection with most of the chiefs by 1884. However, while some, like Calabar and Bonny, had allowed missionaries to operate in their states, others had not. Moreover, all of them were insisting on their sovereign rights to regulate trade and to levy duties on British traders. This, the new British consuls, such as Hewett and Johnston, would not tolerate. A typical example of the rulers who stood up to the British consuls and missionaries was Jaja of Opobo (see Plate 6.3). But they conformed to a pattern already familiar to the local chiefs, not all of whom approved. Some, however, paraded a superficial Westernization in their dress, their homes, their food and drink and their way of life. The spread of civilization would be an incidental by-product which the palm-oil trade, limited to coastal transactions, could not achieve on its own. 47 Thus the Protestant missions, very much of this world, took on the role of reformers, which included interfering in political and military strategy. From their position of strength, the missions did not object to the rival intrusion of Western administrations, but counterbalanced it by siding with or against the established trade. Around 1850 the missions, together with the traders and the political administration, became involved in an irreversible process leading to an early form of colonial rule. The excuse given by international diplomacy was always that such actions were aimed at the radical and final suppression of the slave trade. In reacting to the British, the peoples of the area in question, like those in French West Africa, resorted to all the options open to them, those of confrontation, alliance and submission or a combination of any of these options. Let us analyse what happened in Asante, Southern Nigeria and in Northern Nigeria as cases in point.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.704, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in West Africa, 1880-1914', 'section_title': 'Conquest and reaction in British West Africa, 1880-1900 > Southern Nigeria', 'content': 'Mainly as a result of the activities of the missionaries, British influence and trade had penetrated from Lagos, occupied in 1851, to most parts of Yorubaland, and a number of anti-slave trade, and trade and protection treaties had been concluded between the British and many Yoruba rulers by 1884. In 1886, the British administration was also able to convince Ibadan and the Ekitiparapo (comprising the Ekiti, Ijesha and Egba), who had been at war since 1879, to sign a peace treaty. That the British had accomplished so much in Yorubaland by 1886 should not surprise us. Apart from the activities of the European traders and missionaries, which had preceded the wars, after fighting among themselves since the 1850s, the Yoruba were themselves war-weary and needed peace; hence their acceptance of the intervention by the British. The only state in Yorubaland that had effectively resisted the missionaries, the British traders, and the Lagos administration, until the 1880s was Ijebu. Bent on occupying Yorubaland from the early 1890s, the British decided to teach Ijebu a lesson and at the same time demonstrate to the remaining Yoruba states the futility of opposing them.$^{46}$ Using an alleged insult to Governor Denton in 1892 as a pretext, the British launched a wellprepared expedition of about 1000 men armed with rifles, machine guns and a Maxim gun. The Ijebu courageously raised an army of between 7000 and 10000 men but in spite of this huge numerical superiority and in spite of the fact that some of them were armed with firearms, they were routed by the invaders.$^{47}$ It would appear that all the remaining Yoruba states learnt a lesson from this invasion, and it is not surprising that between 1893 and 1899 Abeokuta, Ibadan, Ekiti-Ijesa and Oyo readily agreed to negotiate treaties and accepted British residents. It was merely to ensure the total submission of the Alafin that the British bombarded Oyo in 1895. Abeokuta remained nominally independent until 1914.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Niger delta > The eastern delta', 'content': 'In addition to the British consuls and naval officers on the coast, British traders and missionaries tried to get into the hinterland, for example, by sponsoring voyages of exploration. Many decades of British efforts to discover the course and sources of the Niger river were crowned with success when Richard and John Lander were brought from Aboh to Nembe (Brass) by its ruler, King Boy Amain, in 1830. Once the estuaries of the many rivers of the Niger delta were shown to be the entrance to the great Niger river, British interest was greatly increased in the area as a highway into the rich interior of Nigeria and West Africa. British traders, such as Macgregor Laird, as well as humanitarians and missionaries tried to move up the delta into the hinterland between the 1830s and 1850s.
In the eastern delta itself, the Church Missionary Society under the leadership of the Nigerian ex-slave, Bishop Samuel Ajayi Crowther, estab› lished missions at Bonny in 1864, at Twon-Brass in the Nembe kingdom in 1868, at Elem Kalahari (New Calabar in the documents) in 1874, and at Okrika in 1880. Both at Bonny and Nembe, the rulers invited the missionaries for a number of reasons. Some wished to have the missionaries establish schools in which their children could learn to read, write and speak English in order to carry on their commercial relations with British firms. It was also believed that permission for the missionaries would lead to better relations with the British government, represented by the consuls and naval officers, and serve to strengthen them against neighbouring states in internal power struggles. These same reasons sometimes led to the missionaries being rejected in other parts of the eastern delta. Thus, once the Church Missionary Society was established at Bonny, Jaja of Opobo, who had broken away from Bonny in 1869 to form his state of Opobo, would have nothing to do with that mission. The establishment of Christian missions was, however, resisted by powerful interests within each of the delta states, and Christianity constituted a factor of social instability in the nineteenth century. Dike considered that Christianity turned the slaves into revolutionaries who created upheavals in these states; but recent research has discovered other social and political factors to explain the problems of the delta states in the nineteenth century. 7', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Dahomey, Yorubaland, Borgu and Benin in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'The growth of European interest', 'content': 'The events that marked the real turning point, however, were the formal annexation of Lagos to the British Crown in 1861 and a British naval action against Porto Novo later the same year.$^{34}$ These two British actions naturally sensitized the French, who had considerable commercial interests in Whydah and Porto Novo. Encouraged by Porto Novo itself, a French protectorate was declared over this coastal Aja state in 1863 to check further British advance along the coast to the west. Both the British and the French soon discovered the obvious: that the real value of Lagos or Porto Novo was to be measured in terms of the trade with the hinterland in the Yoruba and Aja interior which the two ports shared. This involvement of both Britain and France in the trade and politics of Lagos and Porto Novo respectively sparked off a spell of dramatic rivalry between the two powers in a bid to control Yorubaland, especially the western parts, and the adjacent Aja-speaking communities. In this Anglo-French rivalry, western Yorubaland became the main theatre because of the positive response of the local peoples, who saw in the European interventions the solution to the problem of the continuous invasion of their area by their more powerful neighbours.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Liberia and Ethiopia, 1880-1914: the survival of two African states', 'section_title': 'European aggression on Liberian and Ethiopian territory, 1880-1914 > Liberia', 'content': "Heeding invitations by the Vai of north-western Liberia, and Sierra Leonean and British merchants stationed on the Vai coast, and mindful of Sierra Leone's commerce and revenue, Britain intervened from i860 allegedly to protect the Vai and the merchants from Liberian impositions. After fruitless, intermittent discussions between British, Liberian and Vai representatives, Britain annexed most of the Vai chiefdoms to Sierra Leone in March 1882, although the Vai chiefs never desired British rule (save British intervention) (see Fig. 11.3).$^{23}$ Liberians, stunned by the British action, but helpless, issued an emotional, ineffective 'Memorandum and Protest' against the action, copies of which were sent to all nations with which Liberia had treaty relations. It implored these nations to aid Liberia and to mediate 'to arrest a course of events which threaten her destruction'. Among the few governments to reply was that of the United States, to which Liberians particularly looked for intervention to secure 'a just arrangement' of the boundary question. But the United States government promptly advised Liberia to acquiesce at the British action, which dimmed the hopes of the Liberians entirely. Most of the other nations appealed to were European and were themselves intensifying existing expansionism or about to seek territorial aggrandizement in Africa. Hence Liberia's appeal fell mostly on deaf or unsympathetic ears.$^{24}$ In November 1885 Liberia signed an agreement with Britain which fixed the boundary with Sierra Leone at the River Mano to Liberia's disadvantage.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Cameroon coast and its hinterland 14', 'content': "British interest in the abolition of the slave trade and the establishment of legitimate trade led to treaties and the gradual loss of the sovereignty of the local rulers. Although the treaty of 1833 between Nicolls and King William was rejected, British agents concluded treaties between 1840 and 1844 that provided them with the legal basis for intervention in local politics. Such interventions often involved the use of British gunboats to bully chiefs who violated the terms of these treaties, or to collect trade debts owed to Europeans. In 1852 John Beecroft even presided at the election of a new chief of Akwa Town. Sometimes British intervention and arbitration was invited by local rulers: for example, by King William to establish his authority over Bimbia and Rio del Rey. But the more frequent excuse for British intervention arose from the disputes between European and local traders over the repayment of credit or 'trust'. In 1856, the system of arbitration and settlement of disputes between Africans and Europeans was institutionalized in a Court of Equity established at Duala.
The missionaries represented an important element of foreign influence. In 1843, Joseph Merrick, a West Indian mulatto, was sent to Fernando Po by the British Baptist Mission Society. In the same year he established a mission at Bell Town, and in 1844, at Bimbia.$^{21}$ He and his colleagues gradually built churches, schools, carpenters' workshops and, at Bimbia, a printing press. Local opposition was soon aroused by efforts at mass conversion. Conflicts with the missionaries became intensified in the 1850s because of smallpox epidemics, inter-ethnic wars and famines, and the British had to intervene to protect the missionaries and their converts. When the Spanish governor proclaimed Catholicism as the official religion of Fernando Po in 1858, the position of the Baptists became untenable at Clarence. Accordingly, Alfred Saker built a new settlement at Ambas Bay which he named Victoria, in June 1858. But local opposition to the Baptists continued to be high, especially as many of the Anglo-West Indian settlers at Victoria also traded in competition with the Bimbia population.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.711, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Dahomey, Yorubaland, Borgu and Benin in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'The growth of European interest', 'content': "In discussing the growth of European interest in the area of West Africa under review, it is useful to distinguish between two phases: that of freedom of movement for the European powers involved up to 1861 when Lagos was annexed to the British Crown, and the succeeding era of international rivalry between France and Britain with Germany entering the competition in the 1880s. This latter phase terminated only with the partition of the area between Britain and France in 1889. In all this, however, the point to emphasize is that the pattern of European activities at any particular time in the region was as much in response to the European metropolitan demands as to the stimulus of the local situation.
In the earlier phase European traders, explorers or travellers and Chris› tian missionaries operated in Africa without much concern for the national identities of the individual agents. A famous German explorer like Heinrich Barth served 'an official British expedition', while a British explorer of the calibre of H. M. Stanley was in the service of King Leopold of Belgium. Major Christian missionary bodies such as the Church Missionary Society (CMS) of the Church of England and the Lyons-based SociØtØ des Missions Africaines (SMA) of the Roman Catholic Church each employed a mix of European nationals. Father Boghero, who led the SMA in an effort to re› introduce Roman Catholic Christianity to West Africa in the nineteenth century, was an Italian. The pioneer SMA Fathers in most parts of the area which became Nigeria were French, just as it was such British missionaries as Thomas Birch Freeman of the Methodists and Samuel Ajayi Crowther of the CMS who pioneered the work of Christian missions in what was to become French Dahomey (present-day People's Republic of Benin).$^{33}$ British, French, German and Portuguese traders set up businesses adjacent to one another and, as the case of Badagry clearly demonstrated, there were residential quarters for diverse European nationals in the major ports all along the coast of the Bight of Benin.
Traders moved back and forth between the coastal ports in search of the most favourable terms of trade, and according to the varying fortunes of the ports and the states whose economies came to depend increasingly on the coastal trade.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.696, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Conclusion: Africa on the eve of the European conquest', 'section_title': 'The changing balance of power', 'content': "Similarly, most African leaders were very suspicious of European missionaries. Eventually many welcomed missionaries if they played down the factor of conversion and emphasized education. Many rulers welcomed the opportunity for some of their slaves, or even their sons, to acquire the skills of reading and writing as a key to the white man's knowledge, and as a basis of commercial relations. The missionaries were even more welcome when they taught new technologies such as the printing of books, house-building, mechanized farming, vaccination, and the like. They were also sometimes called upon to teach techniques for making guns, gun› powder and other strategic goods, or at least to assist with their importation. By the 1870s, it was becoming clearer that the process of acculturation was weakening the identity of the host states, and their resolve to maintain their independence. Missionary activities also became a factor of division conditioning some African states to support particular European nationals and others to oppose.
Perhaps the most subversive of the European activities was trade. Trade provided a basis for co-operation between Africans and Europeans, as both had a mutual interest in promoting its expansion. African rulers had to regulate trade for strategic reasons and to ensure that the African state and African merchants derived as much advantage from it as possible.
