Ultimately it was agreed that the Liverpool Chamber should join with the Manchester Chamber in their petition.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1885#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Two events of the past month are likely to have a lasting influence upon the future of Africa. Perhaps the most important of these is the convention or agreement between Great Britain and Germany, whereby the "sphere of influence" of these two Powers has been clearly defined in regard to territory which has been for a long time the subject of diplomatic dispute, and might have become the occasion of trouble even more serious still. This is a matter the importance of which it is almost impossible to over-estimate.

So long as any Power makes a claim which is considered to be inconsistent with the rights, or fancied rights, of another, not only is there sure to be a considerable amount of friction in the relations of those two Powers, but such a state of things is necessarily very prejudicial to the country concerned, especially when it is only just being opened out to the influences of civilisation. It is for this, among other reasons, that the agreement between Great Britain and Germany will be welcomed by all who are interested in the advance of Africa. With regard to the details of this arrangement, we find that England admits the claim of Germany to...', 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1890#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.691, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Commercial Value of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Altogether our West African possessions do a trade with Great Britain (mainly with Liverpool, London, and Bristol) of about £5,000,000 yearly, give honourable employment to some 770 of our British fellow-countrymen, and bring at least 5,000,000 of intelligent (Sierra Leone), sturdy (Krumen), industrious (Gold Coast), artistic (Yoruba), brave (Niger), good-tempered (Oil Rivers) negroes under our sway. I have dwelt more in detail on the extent of our interests in West Africa than on those which we possess in other parts of the Continent, because it is with West Africa that the inhabitants and commerce of the United Kingdom are most concerned. I mean that the trade of our West African possessions, and the employment given to British subjects, are directed almost solely to Great Britain. If we gave away the Gold Coasts or Lagos, or the Niger, for instance, in exchange for concessions from France or Germany in the Pacific or the North Atlantic, the ratio of loss to the inhabitants of Great Britain would be far greater than the gain to the Australians or the Newfoundlanders. To those who argue that our missionaries and merchants might go on working in West Africa just the same, even if the rule in our possession were transferred to another Power, I would ask, 'How many British merchants are there in French Senegambia? What is the total of British trade with the French, German, Belgian, Portuguese possessions in West Africa as compared to that carried on with the districts under the British flag? Are the British missionaries able to conduct their evangelisation in French Africa? In the most enlightened and liberal-minded of these foreign administrations, the German possession of Cameroons, did not the English Baptist Mission, who had laboured there for forty years prior to the German advent, have to leave the country after the German rule was established?' We should not blame the Governments of foreign powers for these results. The fault lies in our peculiar idiosyncrasies as a people. We are of a cranky, self-willed, unaccommodating disposition, tolerably patient under the government of our own fellow-countrymen, but utterly impatient of foreign control. While, however, our possessions of Western Africa are become a necessity to the trade of Liverpool, Manchester, Burnley, Birmingham, Leeds, Sheffield, Bristol, and London, our newly-gained spheres of influence in South Central Africa—besides the important Scotch interests which they concern—are a necessity for the commercial expansion and feeding-ground of our growing British South African Confederation, which has a total population of over 2,000,000, and does a yearly trade with the United Kingdom of £18,000,000 in value. Then as to Zanzibar and British East Africa, they, in their turn, besides securing the southern approach to the dominions of our Egyptian ward, are a necessity to the trade and overflow emigration of our great Indian Empire, with its nearly 300,000,000 of people and its yearly trade with the British Empire of some £90,000,000. The trade of the British Empire with British Africa amounts to about £25,200,000 yearly. Among the more valuable products which British Africa sends us, or supplies to herself, may be cited the following: gold, silver, copper, coal, diamonds, ivory, rubber, palm oil, palm kernels, gums, cotton, dyewoods, indigo, coffee, sugar, rice, Indian corn, horses, cattle, donkeys, hides, amomum seeds, red peppers, and many other valuable dyes, spices, oils, timber, drugs, skins, and farinaceous foods.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1890#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.711, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Upon another page our readers will find the text of a letter which has been addressed by the members of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce to Lord Salisbury, as Foreign Secretary, upon the subject of the boundaries of the territories of the Royal Niger Company in the Oil Rivers Districts. As is perhaps only natural, the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce strongly protested against the extension of the authority of the Royal Niger Company over any portion of the Oil Rivers, and they point out that only two years ago the grant of a Royal Charter was refused to this very district. No doubt the presence of a large trading company, endued with special and exceptional powers, has a tendency to dwarf other commercial undertakings in the same district. But the Government are necessarily swayed by broader considerations than the advantage or disadvantage of certain individual traders. Their chief object is to provide for the administration of the particular district. The existence of chartered companies is only tolerable in uncivilised or semi-civilised countries, where the presence of a strong commercial interest may often enable the governing body to provide for the administration of the district without the great expense that would have to be incurred by the home Government if they attempted the direct administration themselves. The history of the development of India under the fostering rule of the Honourable East India Company proves the correctness of this theory, and to her Majesty's ministers it appears that the Royal Niger Company occupies an analogous position in its own district. The charter which was granted to the Niger Company some years ago is sufficiently careful in safeguarding the interests of others, and the success which has attended its administration of the district in question appears fully to justify an extension of its authority in the direction of the Oil Rivers. Surely the great desideratum is the civilisation and improvement of the long neglected races on the West Coast of Africa, to whom Great Britain owes so vast a debt, and so long as that is accomplished it matters little whether it be effected by a commercial corporation endued with exceptional powers, or be left to be gradually evolved as the result of individual effort—except that in the latter case it will take a much longer time to produce the result aimed at.", 'last_edit_date': '1892-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1892#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.698, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A New African Market for English Manufactures', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. George Baden-Powell recently addressed a letter on this subject to a contemporary, from which we extract the following: Europeans in the middle ages appropriated all it could of America, Africa, and Asia under the pretext of the conversion of the heathen. In these days English expansion penetrates these continents under the plea of exchanging English manufactures for native raw material. Now the Germans on the east and Internationalists on the west are doing their best to open up the interior of Africa to English manufactures. But Englishmen should not forget that on the south the English taxpayer has recently paid for the opening out of a trade route which is capable of tapping all Africa below 10deg. south latitude—a vast district rich in ivory, and probably in gold also, and containing a large population which is rapidly placing a value on English manufactures. Sir Charles Warren has opened up a good road, with watering places and telegraph all along, so far as Shoshong, which is situated at 22deg. south; the whole way lies on a healthy table-land, three to five thousand feet above the sea-level, and connecting at Kimberley with a railway system in direct communication with the Cape Town docks. Provided this new road be preserved free under English control, Shoshong will rapidly become the centre of converging trade routes, tapping all districts lying to the south of the Congo and Zanzibar areas.

Three or four years ago the people around Shoshong made their own copper wire and axe-heads, and clothed themselves in skins of their own killing and curing. Now they are buying English piece-goods, Sheffield hardware, and even Birmingham screws. English goods are steadily and even rapidly advancing northwards into the African interior by this route. English export manufacturers would do well at once to form a committee or syndicate to watch this newly-opened up trade entrance into the populated interior of Central Africa, for it may become at least as important as the Congo or Zanzibar routes.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.688, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ENGLAND AND HER WEST AFRICAN COLONIES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Turning to the question of the political administration of the Colonies at the present time, he enumerated the different systems of government prevailing in the various British Colonies in Africa, and said that the great benefits derived by the Colonies from their annexation to England, whose constitutional monarchy was the most stable system of representative government to be found in the whole world, were conspicuous and great. England had extended to her West African dependencies the privileges of British legitimate trade and commerce, which was a powerful vehicle for the advancement of civilisation.

Bringing forward the commercial advancement of the West African Colonies, he said the question had often been asked, "Do the Colonies pay?" He could answer with an emphatic affirmative. In 1837 the total external trade of England with all the Colonies was £28,341,471; it was now nearly £300,000,000, thus showing an increase of about ten times. The British shipping in connexion with the Colonies in 1837 was 3,677,975 tons; in 1885 it was 56,611,075 tons. The English Customs returns reckoned the exports to the Colonies in 1837 at £11,283,363; and this had since risen to £54,545,553. Her Majesty's Colonies, he said, furnished more than a quarter of the whole world's annual supply of gold. He then referred to the commercial geography of the British African Colonies, gave the value of their exports and imports, and reviewed the trade generally. The construction of a railway to the interior of Africa from Lagos was a recent proposition and a new feature in the history of the West African Colonies. It was obvious that Africa was, or would be, the only continent open for the future expansion of British manufacture; in such a case the interior would play an important part. He maintained, with eminent authorities on the subject, that by native agency alone, under foreign supervision necessarily, could tropical Africa be gradually and definitely developed on any permanent basis, and that the negro should be educated industrially and otherwise with the generous help of Europe and America. Whatever was accomplished by native agency, England certainly should carry the credit of effecting such accomplishment in the civilisation of Africa. It was beyond doubt that the English were acknowledged the best colonisers; and the marked consideration invariably shown by them to the people whom they undertook to govern, the extreme liberty and entire privileges of a British subject extended to every native, and the judicious caution characteristic of the policy of the British Government had altogether won for England this success and the preference to all other civilised nations. From the past and present history they might reasonably hope for the dawning of still better, brighter, and happier days upon the future of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.699, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH ADMINISTRATION IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The present is a very critical time in the history of the British West African Colonies. It is a fact well within the knowledge of all interested in the welfare of the oldest British colony in Africa that for some years past the French, by means of treaties made with the chiefs of the Upper Niger and Western Soudan, have been gradually encroaching upon the hitherto not very well-defined boundaries of the Colony of Sierra Leone, with the result of gradually reducing the British sphere of influence, and at the same time narrowing the field from which the merchants and traders of that Colony draw their native produce, and in which, in return, they have been in the habit of finding a market for their imported goods. Rather more than two years ago, an agreement was concluded at Paris between our Government and that of France with regard to the boundaries of their respective spheres of influence in West Africa. The territories referred to in the agreement were Senegambia, Sierra Leone, the Gold Coast, and the Slave Coast. It was provided that the two Governments should have the right of appointing special Commissions of Delimitation "to trace upon the spot, wherever they may consider it necessary, the line of demarcation between the English and French possessions" in conformity with the agreement. The work of determining the boundary line between Senegambia and Sierra Leone is now about to be begun, the British Commissioners having left Liverpool on Saturday last. For some time past British merchants interested in commerce with Sierra Leone have been apprehensive that their trade with the interior might be seriously interfered with, if not absolutely ruined, by a wrongful definition of the boundary. Our trade with Sierra Leone is mainly dependent upon the caravan traffic between the British port of Freetown and the upper portion of the Niger.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1891#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.706, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The trade between this country and West Africa is capable of almost infinite development. It is now announced that the British Government will recommend Parliament to grant a subsidy to a contractor who is prepared to lay and work a cable between St. Vincent and the chief places on the West Coast. We are sure our readers will rejoice at this further step towards bringing West Africa into closer connexion with England. At present, the three weeks taken by even the fastest postal communication is a serious drawback to the commerce of Lagos, Sierra Leone, and the other West African ports, and the proposed cable will do much to simplify and develop commercial relations between Great Britain and the ports and towns in her West Coast possessions. Further south, we have the still more important district of the Congo. Mr. H. M. Stanley, than whom no greater authority upon the subject exists, seems never to tire of pointing out the advantages which must result from the formation of new markets in the Congo territory; and the decision of the European Powers at the Berlin Conference that Free Trade principles should be established at least for a term of years in the territory of the African International Association will do much towards the development of trade with parts not hitherto reached by commerce. The British Congo Company (Limited), the prospectus of which our readers will find in another column, which may be aptly described as the practical outcome of the Conference's decision, is now announced, with a capital of £500,000, divided into shares of £5 each. The Board of Directors contains many names well known in the African trade. Even under no very favourable circumstances a considerable trade has been for the past few years conducted between this country and the Congo. Last year, the imports into this district amounted to considerably over £880,000, and the exports to nearly £2,000,000—so that in round numbers the present trade may be roughly estimated at between two and a-half and three million pounds per annum. Though only just formed, the British Congo Company (Limited) will scarcely commence as an entirely new undertaking, for, in order to avoid the delays and disadvantages inseparable from an entirely new business, a provisional agreement has been made with the Congo and Central African Company (Limited), of Liverpool, which possesses several factories and stations along the river, and at Ambriz and Ambrizette on the coast, by which the Congo and Central African Company agrees to transfer its stations, factories, and buildings, stores and plant, its steamers, cargo, surf and other boats, to this Company at a valuation, to be paid for by fully paid-up shares in this Company, and to sell its stock of goods, merchandise, and produce to this Company at cost price. No payment will be made for goodwill, the shareholders in that Company being satisfied that they will make a larger profit by becoming interested in a more powerfully-constituted undertaking. This agreement will provide the new Company at once with a favourable basis for its operations, and enable it to enter immediately upon a profitable business in the Lower Congo district, and give great facilities for opening up trade as communications with the Upper Congo are established. Thus we are assured of a speedy increase of an already existing trade in the districts placed under the International African Association, and the British Congo Company (Limited), by possessing stations upon the coast as well as along the course of the river, will be well prepared to participate in the trade which is constantly developing among the peoples in the interior.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1885#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.709, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Progress on the West African Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The African rivers situate in the Bight of Benin, commonly known as the Oil Rivers, have been placed under the protectorate of Great Britain. The protectorate, announced at Bonny, in December last, by Admiral Sir Walter Hunt Grubb, extends from the right bank of Benin river to the Rio del Rey, thus including Brass, New and Old Calabar, Bonny, Opobo, and other important trading stations.

Two series of considerations, the internal and external, have combined to render action imperative, and a retrospective view may not be uninstructive. Since the abolition of the export of slaves, these localities have been the sites of trading stations, palm oil being the chief article of export. The traders have been, with few exceptions, British, and the capitalists mostly Liverpool merchants. The natives allowed trading hulks to be anchored and commerce conducted on payment of fixed sums, known as "comey." Bonny, Brass, and Old Calabar are among the oldest of these trading ports, the native chiefs being also the native traders. They possessed numerous slaves who were sent with merchandise to the interior markets to collect oil, which was brought to the stations and sold to the whites. Among the Bonny chiefs was the father of Ja Ja, late King of Opobo; his son was brought up to the management of the business, and on his father's death he succeeded to his position. Of his enemies the most powerful was Oko Jumbo, who lost no opportunity to humiliate him. The Europeans could only let matters take their course; they regretted constant fighting of Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, but the relations between the Europeans and natives being strictly commercial, nothing could be done. Suffering reverses, Ja Ja was forced to fly with the remnant of his people after great slaughter at the hands of Oko Jumbo. He collected his scattered family, dependants, and slaves, and made his escape to the Opobo river. There Ja Ja found a place for his town, and established himself as King of Opobo.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The history of British commercial connexion with this part of Africa may be briefly told. More than 100 years ago the ships of one or two Liverpool and Bristol merchants were actively engaged in exchanging cargo for slaves, ivory, and palm oil. Fifty years ago the four or five leading houses in the trade were already strong enough to dispense with the profits of slave traffic and rely on the ordinary channels of commerce. It was not, however, without great sacrifices and outlay of money on their part that the change was made palatable to the great native chiefs of the Bights of Benin and Biafra, who had grown immensely wealthy and powerful by the trade in humanity. To induce a better business in native products, loans and presents of cotton goods, hardware, and other articles were made on an extensive scale, and the palm oil trade thus rapidly developed in importance. Examination of the shipping books of one of the greatest firms of that period (1843) shows about forty-six various assortments of articles shipped in twelve months; and the changes brought about by improving civilisation and persistent commercial effort are evidenced in the 300 or more distinct and separate items of export now found in the invoice books of Oil Rivers merchants. Comparative statistics are not available in any authentic form. The quantity of palm oil imported into Europe has varied very little all along, though the tendency has been slightly to increase. A new trade, however, rivalling in dimensions that in oil, has sprung up through the activity of English merchants, and palm kernels—formerly waste product—are bought up in great quantities for shipment to European crushing mills. Ivory has all but disappeared. Ebony and other woods are increasing in volume, and cocoa quickly rising into importance, as well as rubber.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-08-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_08_1891#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.704, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CAPTAIN CAMERON, R.N., ON AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the meeting of the Balloon Society, on July 18, a lecture was delivered by Captain V. Lovett Cameron, R.N., on "Africa."

The lecturer said that the further British influence extended in Africa the more would slavery of every kind be done away with. Besides illegal slavery, there was extensively practised in Africa a system of native despotism which it was very desirable should be abolished. In 1876 nobody seemed to take any notice of Africa, and the exportation of India-rubber from Zanzibar amounted to something under £20,000. Now the amount was about £250,000! With respect to ill-health in that continent, he had found that some of the native treatments were by no means to be despised, and many of our English doctors could take a leaf out of their book. The record of men who had travelled through Africa and endured every conceivable kind of hardship proved that Africa had been cursed by the idea of its unhealthiness, a reproach which it did not deserve. The great thing required, however, was adequate communication. African travelling, under present circumstances, meant, at the outside, fifty miles in a week. At the present time every mile of railroad laid down in Africa drove a dozen nails into the coffin of the slave-trade, to say nothing of the immense impetus to trade and commerce which would thus be afforded. From Cairo right away to the Albert Nyanza was navigable water. There would be no difficulty in overcoming the obstacles of cataracts, &c., which modern engineering would easily surmount. The central high plateau of Africa was, to a great extent, in British hands, and offered the most important means of repressing the slave-trade in future. Every slave working at the present time was in direct defiance of the Act of 1873. Mr. Rhodes' great railway, which would reach Zambesia within eight years, should be kept under British control, as native treaties were more or less uncertain. In 1876 they could have obtained all that is now German territory by holding up their hands. The Germans, however, are practically locked in. A dispute had been going on with Portugal as to whether the Zambesi was an open highway. Fortunately, owing to the twenty-one miles strip of land granted by England to Germany these two powers would be as one on the question, and in future arbitration claim the Zambesi as an open highway. A wise system of emigration should be conducted. He would like to see Indian planters transferred there, and Chinese too. Africa offered an excellent opening for the English working man, and it was desirable that the Government should protect its emigrants. The dangers of Africa were largely dwelt on nowadays, and its advantages were put in the rear. This was the reason why the development of that great continent was so far behind hand.

**Mr. Alvan Millson**, Assistant Colonial Secretary for the Colony of Lagos, delivered an address recently before the members of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce on the subject of Yorubaland.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1891#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.696, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: The British government's failure to fund projects and fulfill promises, coupled with a lack of support for traders, undermined diplomatic and economic relations with African leaders on the Niger River.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that the British government's failure to fund projects and fulfill promises, coupled with a lack of support for traders, undermined diplomatic and economic relations with African leaders on the Niger River. The General History of Africa highlights the British use of treaties and gunboat diplomacy to enforce trade conditions, which eroded local rulers' power and sovereignty, indicating a lack of genuine support for local leaders. British interventions were primarily aimed at securing their own economic interests, often imposing their judicial systems over local laws and straining relations. The resistance from local leaders like Jaja of Opobo against British trade control further exemplifies the undermining of local authority and unfulfilled promises of mutual benefit. However, the textbook does not explicitly mention funding failures. In contrast, The African Times articles specifically address the British government's reluctance to grant subsidies for steam navigation on the Niger, despite promises to local chiefs, due to opposition from private traders. This reluctance, along with the apathy of British officials towards supporting merchants, led to a decline in trade and dishonored commitments to African leaders. The failure to establish trading ports and provide adequate protection and assistance further strained relations. Together, these sources illustrate how British economic and diplomatic practices, including governmental inaction and insufficient support for traders, negatively impacted diplomatic and economic ties with African leaders on the Niger River.

tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that the British government's failure to fund projects and fulfill promises, along with a lack of support for traders, undermined diplomatic and economic relations with African leaders on the Niger River. The articles highlight the British government's reluctance to grant subsidies necessary for establishing steam navigation on the Niger, despite the recognized Imperial policy and promises made to local chiefs. This reluctance is attributed to the influence of private traders who opposed the subsidy, leading to a standstill in efforts to develop the region. Additionally, the articles criticize the apathy of British officials towards supporting British merchants, noting a decline in trade due to inadequate protection and assistance. The failure to fulfill promises of establishing trading ports and the lack of effective government action are seen as dishonoring commitments to African leaders, further straining relations. These observations align with the claim, illustrating how governmental inaction and insufficient support for traders negatively impacted diplomatic and economic ties with African leaders on the Niger River.

[{'document_title': 'The colonial economy: the former British zones', 'section_title': 'Currency and banking', 'content': "These two banks completely dominated banking activities in British West Africa throughout the colonial period. In British East and Central Africa, the National Bank and the Grindlay's Bank also appeared and soon dominated the field. The operations of these banks impeded economic developments in the colonies in three main ways. First, the banks invested all their money in England, including the savings made by the Africans themselves. This meant that they promoted capital formation and therefore economic development of the rich metropolitan country at the expense of the poor colonies. Secondly, and more seriously, recent research has shown that in their lending policies, all the banks discriminated against African entre› preneurs and in favour of the British and Asian population.$^{68}$ Thirdly, since banking became the exclusive preserve of Europeans, Africans were denied the opportunity of acquiring training and experience in this vital field.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The colonial economy: the former British zones', 'section_title': 'Marketing', 'content': "Trade with Britain put African dependencies at a great disadvantage, as was the case during the great depression. In 1932 Imperial Preference was introduced in British dependencies. Imports from the British Empire had customs duties fixed at between 10 and 50% lower than the general level. But since trade between the dependencies was negligible, the intended beneficiary of the arrangement was obviously Britain. In September 1931 the Colonial Office dispatched a circular to officers administering depen› dencies asking them to help Britain and reminding them that: the interests of the United Kingdom and those of the Colonies and Dependencies are inseparably bound up with one another, that the perils which face the United Kingdom are perils which menace the whole Empire ... that any general collapse of British credit and declir - in the exchange value of sterling must spell ruin for the colonies no less than for the United Kingdom. 83 Despite the higher tariff on non-British goods, their importation, to the advantage of consumers in the dependencies, increased greatly. Canvas shoes and artificial silk and cotton clothing, all from Japan, featured promi› nently, and their prices were far below those of British goods which enjoyed protection. In 1934 the district officer of Dar es Salaam, Tanganyika, observed that 'practically every shop in the district'$^{84}$ was stocked with many Japanese goods. The development was especially important during this period of economic distress. As one colonial administrator in Tangan› yika put it, probably with some exaggeration, 'the average African would now be reduced to wearing bark cloth if it were not for the fact that large quantities of cheap cotton goods from Japanese manufacture are exposed for sale in all the town and country shops'.$^{85}$ But the British Government's concern was the success of the British industry and not the welfare of the poor people in the dependencies. In 1934 a further attack was made on non-British goods by raising the tariff to 100%, as a general rule. In addition, a quota system was imposed on the importation of Japanese textiles. There were isolated protests against these measures but the colon› ized people had to pay high prices, thereby promoting imperialist interests at their own expense.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The colonial economy: North Africa', 'section_title': 'Part II: Libya, Egypt and the Sudan > The Sudan > The impact of British colonial economic activities on the Sudan', 'content': 'Compared with those of the French and the Italians in the Maghrib and Tripoli respectively, British colonial economic activities in the Sudan were laudable to some extent. Land was not appropriated by foreigners nor was it concentrated in the hands of a few people as was the case in the other colonies. The Djazïra scheme also proved quite beneficial both to the British and to those people of the Sudan who were directly involved in it. The development of a modern transport system together with the construction of ports and irrigation facilities also helped the growth of a modern agricultural system in the Sudan. However, there is a negative side to this story. First, the infrastructure that was provided was totally inadequate and was clearly meant to promote the interests of Britain more than those of the Sudanese. It is most significant that not one single mile of motor road was constructed in the whole of the Sudan during the period under review while the railway was constructed initially to facilitate British military campaigns and later to promote their cotton and gum projects in Djazïra and the western areas respectively. As in most of the colonies, industrialization was completely neglected. However, the greatest indict› ment against British colonialism in the Sudan is its total neglect of the Southern Sudan economically and socially. This neglect is undoubtedly one of the most important contributory factors to the creation of the southern problem in the Sudan, a problem which has still not been solved.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.649, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The colonial economy', 'section_title': 'Dependence and repression, 1930-8', 'content': "Most capital projects were suspended during the depression; and, where this was not so, the investment was associated with the expansion of cheap primary production and was undertaken with the use of forced labour, as with the French Office du Niger irrigation project. There was an overall revival of coercion in economic relations, indicating that the colonial economy had to be buttressed by non-economic means when in crisis. African labour and taxes kept the railways viable and maintained colonial revenues. Yet, the African masses suffered most from the cutback on already skimpy social services, such as medicine and education, and they had to pay more for these services. In the years of recovery after 1934, wages, prices and facilities for Africans remained retrenched in contrast to the return to high profit levels for private capital.
Colonial governments granted minimum relief to Africans suffering from the depression. They suspended tax collection, and they subsidised prices, as the French did for groundnuts. The above paragraph follows immediately the statement that "promises have been made to those chiefs [in the Niger] that trading ports should be established in their territories." To procure a continuous and dependable steam navigation on the Niger and its tributaries, with the formation of trading ports there, had therefore, to say nothing of the preceding eighteen years, been for the last six years the recognised Imperial policy. Dr. Baikie was maintained in the Niger, in furtherance of this policy, at an expense of not less than 2,000l. a-year. Several voyages of Her Majesty's gunboats up the river had also been made during those years. Dr. Baikie's reports had been published from time to time by Her Majesty's Government, in order to afford information and, as it was evidently hoped, inducements, to the mercantile community. But all had been in vain. Strenuous efforts were made among the African merchants in London and Liverpool to induce them to fulfil the Government desire on the basis of a subsidy. But they either scouted, or lent but an inefficient countenance to, the proposal. Individually and collectively, they would "have none of it." Things remained in this state till the powerful Company of African Merchants, with its fully-subscribed capital of 400,000l., came upon the scene. The opinions and views of persons hitherto not engaged in African trade, but who became shareholders of this company with the express condition that it should co-operate, if possible, with Her Majesty's Government for carrying forward the Imperial policy in the Niger, were now brought to bear on this question. And only thus could any body of merchants, whether as directors of a company or otherwise, have been brought to consent to take upon themselves the great labour, as well as risk, of such an enterprise. The field, as already stated, had been long open—no one stepped in to occupy it—all turned their backs on it, until the Company of African Merchants, acting under the impulse already described, agreed to enter on certain conditions, such as had been on a former occasion accepted by Her Majesty's Government for a very much smaller service. One department of Her Majesty's Government had been year after year calling out to its agents on their watch-tower, "Sister Anne, Sister Anne, is there any one coming—any one to place steam navigation on the Niger, and to enable us to redeem those promises we have made, again and again, to the chiefs, the nonfulfilment of which dishonours and disgraces this country?" At last the hoped-for one appears—appears, in efficient form—appears, fully capable in every way of giving the required aid. And then in step the African merchants to protest against the work being done in the only way in which it can be accomplished. They call upon the Government to stultify itself in all it has been doing for years past. They say, throw away the ten or twenty thousand pounds you have spent on Dr. Baikie and on gunboat expeditions up the river during the last six years. And why, forsooth? For this only reason, as appears by the memorials—this: we cannot and will not eat the hay ourselves, and we will not that others eat of it. This dog in the manger system is nothing new in the world. But that it should have succeeded with the department that holds the purse-strings of the Government and nation, seems to us inexplicable. But alas! such has been the fact. Instead of meeting the opponents with, "Gentlemen, this navigation of the Niger—this trade in the Niger—has long been a cherished desire of Her Majesty's Government; will you undertake it as efficiently as has been proposed to us, and on better terms than have been proposed to us?" the department says, "We think you are right—so you will not and cannot eat hay, it would really be very hard that anybody else should be allowed to do so; it would be hard to see others feeding, and the nation rejoicing, where you cannot and will not eat. He at once armed all the people there, and sent them overland to Changally, while he went by water. They arrived in time. his son quiet in future. Hutton, President of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce, in his address at the annual meeting of the Chamber on Feb. 1, said that a matter which had engaged the attention of the directors was our trade with West Africa, particularly in the neighbourhood of the rivers Niger and Binue. They had to complain very much of the apathy manifested by the resident officials of Her Majesty's Government, who taxed the goods, but declined to afford any protection or assistance to British merchants. Those officials seemed to have an idea that they were sent out to rule and not to assist as much as possible in the development of British trade. Owing to the state of affairs which had been allowed to arise in the localities indicated, the trade in this country had suffered a very marked decline, for whereas in 1884 we sent 106,000,000 yards of cotton goods, representing a value of £1,320,000, we only sent last year 73,000,000 yards, or a money value of £851,000. He submitted that the Government ought to take prompt measures to protect the lives and property of British subjects in West Africa, and so assist in extending a very valuable market for English manufactures. They had just heard that last May, on the invitation of the German Government, Her Majesty's Government gave to Germany an assurance that a Congo International Conference should be pledged to the British Protectorate in the Niger, that only moderate duties should be levied, and that those should only be levied for the purpose of paying the expenses necessary to carry out the obligations of the Protectorate. At the same time it was understood that there should be no monopolies there, and those concessions were made without giving those who were really owners of property in the territories any voice in the country whatever. Two of the special objects of the merchants in obtaining these concessions from the natives and in obtaining the treaties of sovereignty and territory were that we should do the very utmost we could to stop the importation of spirits into the districts. You are right, gentlemen. Rather than this, let the French take possession of the Niger, and exclude us."', 'last_edit_date': '1864-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.705, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It is indeed impossible to read his article and to review the events of the last ten years without contrasting the apathy of British Colonial Government on the West Coast of Africa with the extraordinary foresight and energy displayed by the Royal Niger Company, which Mr. Thomson has selected as his principal theme. It may be confidently affirmed that, but for the patriotic and courageous action of that Company, the Lower and Middle Niger would have passed into the hands of France, which now holds the Upper Niger; while the Benue and Chad Basin would have fallen to the lot of Germany. The efforts still being made by France to extend southward and eastward from Senegambia, point to the conclusion that, but for the Niger Company, British influence would have been for ever excluded from Western Africa, with the exception of the narrow strips of coast line which form our British Colonies and which depend necessarily for their development on those inner regions which would have passed into the hands of foreign powers.

Mr. Thomson points out that this struggle, which extended over several years, and in which the Niger Company—then known as the National African Company—risked its existence, was entirely unsupported by the British Government, and would probably have never received any recognition but for necessities resulting from the Berlin Conference. We must, however, demur to Mr. Thomson's view that Downing Street is responsible for the apathy displayed up to a recent date in developing the British West African Colonies, and in securing for England her share of the African Continent. Downing Street, after all, is the servant and not the master of public opinion, which it can, indeed, do much to lead, but which it cannot compel to follow. It seems to us that Downing Street has shown its capacity by seizing on the bound this outburst of popular enthusiasm for the benefit of the empire and of civilisation.

Mr. Thomson has based his arguments on the record of the Niger Company—because, having been the longest established, it has had time to plant its stations in the heart of Africa, and to establish British "political and commercial supremacy over the entire Central Soudan;" but he refers also "to the Imperial British East Africa Company, whose first yearly report tells a tale of work and progress, of which they have a right to be proud," and he concludes his article with a strong opinion that "in chartered companies alone is there hope for the development of British influence, commerce, and civilisation in Africa." The future will show whether he is correct in this view; but it is evident that public opinion is, at any rate at present, on his side. This being so, the experiment must be fairly tried, and its progress will be watched with interest by all who have at heart the future of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1889#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.709, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger Trouble', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A leading article in the same paper goes on to remark that the letter of "African Merchant" expresses the sentiments of the African trade generally outside the Royal Niger Company; but we imagine the writer has misconstrued the Foreign Office statement about a return to the old system being "impracticable, even if it were desirable." "African Merchant" himself must recognize that such retrogression is not practicable, for it would involve leaving the Niger region to the land-grabbing operations of foreigners with a colonization craze. The British Government wished to prevent a foreign protectorate, and they were glad to find persons prepared to save them trouble and expense. They jumped at the offer of the National African Company, and were not too particular about the effect of entrusting the taxing and administrative powers to a party of traders who might be tempted to handicap competitors to secure to themselves a practical monopoly. It is true that the Charter purports to preserve the rights of other traders, but due and licence charges are doing the monopolists' work on the Niger. What Liverpool merchants ask is that the Charter shall be revoked, and the administrative powers conferred on a non-trading organization. In the present company the dual position of governors and traders is anomalous, and leaves the management open to suspicion. The quotation from the Foreign Office letter suggests that Lord Salisbury has misconceived the desires of independent merchants and traders. They do not wish to return to the old system, but to secure such arrangements as will prevent the trade of the Niger being injured for the benefit of a chartered and limited company. They have established a case for that inquiry which should have preceded the grant of a charter. The incubus is the more galling from the circumstance that authority is conferred on a new company, to the detriment of merchants engaged in the trade of the rivers forming the Niger delta. Before the Government adopted so important a step as chartering one set of traders, they should have obtained the views of merchants who know something of the region in question. So far, the agents of the company do not appear to have achieved any administrative triumphs; their capacity seems to be limited to providing fellow-traders with grievances and driving out of the river the smaller class of traders. Such, at least, is the view of Liverpool merchants in the African trade, and their story should be investigated, and not officially pooh-poohed.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1887#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.704, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger Trouble', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At a recent meeting of the African Trade Section of the Liverpool Chamber of Commerce, the following resolution was carried: "That the members of the African Trade Section are of opinion that the charter granted to the Royal Niger Company, Limited, constitutes a virtual monopoly of the trade of the Niger district, thereby affecting prejudicially British interests in the adjoining rivers. The charter was obtained on the statement that all other European interests in that district had been bought up, which is not the case, and the members of the section are therefore of opinion that the charter should be revoked." It was further resolved that the Council of the Chamber should be asked to adopt the resolution and forward copies of it to certain members of the Government, members of Parliament, and Chambers of Commerce.

A letter from the Colonial Office relating to the administration of the Gold Coast was read. In it Sir H. Holland stated that the Government had consented that the Sefwhi country should on certain conditions be included in the British Protectorate, and he trusted that this action, together with the appointment of Captain Lonsdale as a Commissioner to visit the native tribes, will conduce to a reopening of the roads and an improvement and development of trade.

The *Liverpool Courier* has published the correspondence between Mr. W. F. Lawrence, M.P. for the Abercornby Division, and the Foreign Office on this burning subject.

In a subsequent issue of the *Courier*, a correspondent, signing himself "African Merchant," points out that "one passage in the Foreign Office letter of 27th January last is deserving of special attention—viz., a return to the old system is 'impracticable, even if it were desirable.' Such a declaration is astounding, and an outrage upon common sense. What are the facts? A company not long in existence has been granted sovereign rights and taxing powers over the imports and exports of from five to eight millions of people, and no company trading for its own benefit can exercise such powers in an impartial manner. Powers such as these can only be properly used by an independently-organized body, altogether unconnected with trade. Probably the Government having negotiated treaties with countries up the Niger, were glad to transfer their responsibility to the first who asked for it. Nominally there was to be no monopoly, but practically the greater number of traders are entirely debarred from doing business, and instead of there being free trade, open to all comers, the trade is absolutely shut up. Civilization is not promoted, but thrown back for an indefinite period of time.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1887#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.71, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger Trouble', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"The preamble to the Charter states that the Royal Niger Company has bought up the business of all traders in those regions. This allegation is misleading. For a great number of years, a large trade has been conducted by firms at Liverpool, Bristol, &c., with the rivers forming the delta of the Niger. The Royal Charter is damaging the trade of the merchants here and of the traders in the oil rivers with whom they have so long dealt. The only remedy is a revocation of the present, and the granting of a fresh charter to an independent organization. The Deputy-Governor states that the natives have unreservedly placed themselves in the hands of the company. They know nothing of the Royal Charter or of the British Government, except that they are occasionally bombarded by gunboats, and they could not understand what the Charter meant if the subject was put before them. If the natives are incapable of understanding the Royal Charter, they have not understood what they were doing when they were induced to sign acts of cession in favour of the company. Although treaties are said to have been concluded with '237 tribes and states,' only 37 treaties are scheduled at the end of the Royal Charter! A Commission should have been sent to the coast to inquire and report, previous to granting a charter, but as that was not done, an inquiry ought to be undertaken now; if this is taken up by the Government, only one result can happen, and that is the revocation of the Charter."', 'last_edit_date': '1887-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1887#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.708, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'NAVIGATION OF THE RIVER NIGER.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'If we have been silent since July last on the subject of the navigation of the river Niger, it is not because we have become indifferent thereto, but merely that we have been unable till the present month to insert the residue of the papers laid before the House of Commons in June, 1864. They will now show our readers on what grounds the merchants engaged in the African trade at Liverpool, Bristol, and London opposed the grant of that subsidy, on condition of receiving which the Company of African Merchants had signified their willingness to undertake the great enterprise of the continuous steam navigation of the river Niger for a period of five years, certain. And with all due respect for those gentlemen, we must say that, in our humble opinion, they are not such as ought to have influenced the Treasury to declare against the subsidy, in the face of the express recommendation of the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs and the known approval of Lord Palmerston. They are not such, for many reasons. And among these stands prominently forth the fact that the withholding of the grant by the Treasury was a direct reversal of the policy of Her Majesty's Government since 1840, especially confirmed during the past six years. In Letter No. 5 of these Parliamentary papers,* being copy of a despatch from Mr. Layard, in the name of Earl Russell, the following paragraph occurs:—

"I am to state that the only object Her Majesty's Government have had in view in maintaining Dr. Baikie's expedition in the interior of Africa, for the last six years, has been to prepare the way for opening out the Niger and its tributaries to the commerce of this country, and, by developing legitimate commerce, to strike at the root of the slave-trade."', 'last_edit_date': '1864-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.731, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In New Calabar River, in the Niger delta—a native river—war having broken out, our Consul, who is a smart, clever man, intervened at once, and as one side declined to cease fighting, he ordered a gunboat to the place to protect the trade. But in this, a British river, our property may be looted or burnt, our servants, so long as they were not born in a British settlement, may be slaughtered, while aid or protection we have none. Perhaps, on the principle of killing a director on an English railway, if the Marabouts of Badibboo were to beat or shoot our Administrator, the Government would wake up, and show some of their boasted "spirited foreign policy."—Yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1879-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1879#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH TRADE IN THE NIGER REGION', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'During the time since the discovery by an Englishman of the Niger-Binue these rivers have been unrestrictedly open to the trade of all nations, but the opportunity has been utilized only in two instances. During the years 1879—82 two French companies entered the Niger. One of these, with a capital of £600,000, has extensive establishments on the Senegal coast, and is managed by gentlemen of very great African experience and of high intelligence. It has lately withdrawn entirely from the Niger-Binue, owing to the severity of the competition and to the difficulty of carrying on a successful business there. The other French company, with a capital of £120,000, has, for similar reasons, withdrawn one half of its capital and taken up the other half in shares in the great British company which has solved the problem of successful working in the heart of Africa; so that the trade of the Niger-Binue basin remains solely under British law and British management as formerly. Meanwhile British influence and the advance of British trade and missionaries into the interior have sensibly diminished, and will, ere long, destroy the slave trade and the use of slave caravans—the curse of Central Africa.

Such is the record of Great Britain in the Niger-Binue. The claims arising from first discovery may be set aside as unpractical; the enterprise, the risks, the loss of capital and life during the past half-century of British private individuals and firms in opening up the Niger-Binue to civilization, may be considered as without force in international law; the Christianising efforts of her missionaries may be disregarded; even the British Government exploring expeditions, so numerous and so costly in money and in life—the climate being then so little understood—and even the Parliamentary subsidies to trade, may be considered insufficient to establish British rights in the Niger-Binue. Great Britain has a more valid political claim than any of these. She alone has, since the discovery of these waters, taken upon herself the maintenance of order and the keeping open of these rivers to the trade of all nations; her Consuls alone have acted consistently and successfully as dispensers of justice not only between the traders, but between the native tribes themselves; her gunboats alone have policed the rivers and restrained evil-doers. To Great Britain alone—to her Government, her missionaries, and her commercial establishments—is due such progress as civilization has made on the Niger-Binue.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1884#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH TRADE IN THE NIGER REGION', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Whatever may be the result of the Conference at Berlin, one important advantage will have been gained—viz., the opening of the eyes of Great Britain to the unassisted part that she has played during the past fifty years in the development of Central Africa north of the equator, and to her rights and duty to continue to act as the protector of the Lower Niger and Binue rivers, which, with their important tributaries, form one system which I will designate as the Niger-Binue. This term is in contradistinction to the Upper Niger, from Timbuctoo to the sources, which runs for a distance of 1,000 miles at the back of the French colony of Senegal, and which has been visited by several French exploring parties, though as yet no European trade has been opened there. Nor, indeed, can such trade be carried on profitably until the completion of the railway connecting the waterways of the Senegal and the Upper Niger. Between the latter and the Niger-Binue lies the long stretch of the Middle Niger, from Timbuctoo to Boussa; nature thus interposing a barrier of 800 miles between the Upper Niger basin, which will probably fall to France, and the Niger-Binue basin, which is already occupied by Great Britain. The Niger-Binue was unknown to Europe fifty-five years ago. The wildest theories were held as to the ultimate destination of the Niger—some geographers holding that it was absorbed by an inland sea, others that it fell into the Nile, others that it joined the Congo. The English traveller, John Lander, in 1831 solved the problem by starting from Badagry, and travelling northwards till he reached the Niger, near Boussa, where are the lowest rapids, and where commences the Niger-Binue system. He followed the river down 600 miles to the sea. Immediately on his return home, in 1832, his great discovery was turned to account by some Liverpool merchants, who despatched two steamers to nearly the highest navigable point on the Niger, and to Dagbo on the Binue. This policy was carried on with much determination during the Second Empire, but has been pursued more vigorously than ever since the conclusion of the war with Germany. On the 10th of this month Reuter's agents informed us that a French officer, a Captain Combes, had taken up an excellent position on the Upper Niger; that three posts—Bamakou, Kondou, and Bafoulabé—were provisioned for twelve months, and telegraphic communication established between them. They further added that the launch of the French gunboat now on the Niger was preparing to descend the stream to Timbuctoo with the rising of the waters. At first sight there may appear nothing of importance in all this; but a glance at the map will show that it is a serious step towards the barring out of British trade with that part of the interior of Africa.

As far back as 1849 one of the most energetic and far-seeing of the Governors of the Gambia—the late Sir Richard Graves MacDonnell—writing to Earl Grey on his travels in Bondou, a fertile territory between the Upper Gambia and Senegal, says: "I had frequent interviews with the Almamy, or the Mohammedan Sovereign of Bondou, and was successful in inducing him to enter into an agreement to protect travellers through his country to the Gambia, on receiving certain annual presents from the merchants. Raffenel, p. 484.)', 'last_edit_date': '1885-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.705, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE NIGER', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A well-known authority on Africa, Mr. Capper, stated in a letter to the Times last September, that for nearly 400 years Great Britain had traded with the seaboard of Africa, but had never got any further, save in the instance of the Royal Niger Company. At the mouths of seven of the so-called "oil rivers"—viz., Benin, Brass, New Calabar, Bonny, Opobo, Quaebo, and Old Calabar—British traders have carried on trade with the races of the coast. These tribes act as middlemen between the British merchants and the producing tribes of the interior, and must absorb a large share of the profits of the trade. It is an example of the lethargy into which long-established trades are apt to fall, that, until quite recently, no effort has been made by any of the "oil river" merchants to break down the monopoly of the middlemen and to penetrate into the interior. The black middlemen of the rivers Benin, Bonny, Opobo, Macebo, and Old Calabar draw their produce from regions untapped by the main Niger and its affluents. In the two others, Brass and New Calabar, complaints have been raised by canoemen of having to pay the duties levied by the Niger Company, but as these canoes, which combine slave-hunting with trade, were only able in the past to penetrate into the lower parts of the Niger, if in strong force and well armed with rifles, they may find a compensation in the security with which they now visit their old markets and many others which the development of trade has created. These Brass men were, until recently, the terror of the inhabitants of the lower river, and often turned the cannon which they managed to obtain on the steamers of the enterprising firms who were opening up their insignificant river. hh: Liberia's diplomatic efforts and treaty ratifications with European nations underscore its recognition and strategic cooperation with international powers, contingent on aligning with European and American economic interests.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide a nuanced perspective on Liberia's diplomatic efforts and treaty ratifications with European nations, highlighting both support for and complications to the claim regarding its recognition and strategic cooperation with international powers. The General History of Africa notes Liberia's engagement with international powers, such as the 1885 boundary agreement with Britain and the 1935 negotiations with Firestone and the United States, suggesting a level of recognition and cooperation. However, it also emphasizes Liberia's struggles with foreign control, such as the annexation of Vai chiefdoms by Britain and the imposition of an International Receivership, indicating that Liberia's diplomatic efforts were often undermined by European and American economic interests. Additionally, Liberia's exclusion from the Berlin Conference and pressure to conform to European principles challenge the notion of strategic cooperation. Similarly, The African Times highlights Liberia's treaty ratifications with countries like the Netherlands, Sweden, and Norway, and its recognition by Great Britain, underscoring efforts to align with European economic interests. Yet, it also points out challenges such as internal financial troubles, the perception of Liberia as a virtual French protectorate, and its reluctance to allow foreign land ownership, which complicate its diplomatic standing. Together, these sources illustrate Liberia's diplomatic recognition and efforts to cooperate with international powers, while also highlighting the broader context of foreign intervention and internal challenges that complicate the claim.

[{'id': 424, 'article_title': 'General Observations', 'full_section_title': 'General Observations', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1864#article-10', 'issue_date': '23_08_1864', 'content': '**GENERAL OBSERVATIONS.**

**COTTON.**—The quantity of clean cotton shipped from the Gold Coast, from February last to July, amounts to above thirty tons.

**COFFEE.**—A vessel belonging to the Company of African Merchants (Limited) has lately brought to Liverpool, among other valuable cargo, 425 bags of coffee.

**SIERRA LEONE EXHIBITION.**—The subscriptions in Sierra Leone now amount to 800l., including 100l. promised by Governor D'Arcy, of the Gambia.

**CAPE COAST.**—The whole of the troops have been withdrawn from the Prah, and the stores, &c., destroyed.

**RIVER GAMBIA.**—Postage stamps are to be adopted here.

**RATIFICATIONS** of treaties of amity, commerce, and navigation between the Netherlands and Liberia, and Sweden and Norway and Liberia, have been exchanged in London between the Ministers of Sweden and the Netherlands and Mr. Gerard Ralston, Consul-General for Liberia in Great Britain.

**SLAVE-TRADE.**—The celebrated steam slaver Ciceron, so nearly captured lately off the Dahoman coast, ran from thence to St. Thomas (West Indies). Her captain was so far from admiring the Armstrong shot, dangerously near him during the chase, that he gave up the command, and has returned to Biscay. The Ciceron is the property of that notorious slavedealer, Julian de Zulueta, of Havana, and we have reason to believe will soon reappear in the Bight of Benin in search of a "cargo!"

**AFRICAN ARMY SURGEONS.**—We see with surprise that Dr. Horton, the native African surgeon who rendered such great service during the entire stay of the troops on the Ashantee frontier, has been ordered from Cape Coast to the Gambia. Is this intended as a reward?

**ABEOKUTA.**—The authorities have definitively refused to allow the English property there, said to amount to 100,000l., to be brought down to Lagos, until their war with the Ibadans has been brought to a close.

**LAGOS.**—The number of resident Europeans, which in January was eighty, is now only thirty-five, in consequence of deaths, and removals owing to the continued stoppage of trade with Abeokuta.

**EXPORT OF SPECIE FROM SIERRA LEONE.**—Great complaint continues to be made at the heavy amounts shipped for England by every mail. The Calabar brought several thousand pounds. We hope the contemplated banking operations of the Company of African Merchants in Freetown will prove a remedy for this prejudicial drain of coin.

Governor Freeman, of Lagos, has again returned to England.'}, {'id': 3182, 'article_title': 'Marriage', 'full_section_title': 'Marriage', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1876#article-23', 'issue_date': '01_08_1876', 'content': "**MARRIAGE.**

**COOPER—WILES.**—Married, on the evening of the 31st of May last past, at the large and commodious dwelling house of the bride's father, in Ashmun-street, by the Rev. C. A. Pitman, pastor of the Methodist Episcopal Church, Monrovia, Florence Irene, eldest child and only daughter of the Honourable J. T. Wiles, Secretary of the Treasury, Republic of Liberia, and Jessie Randolph, eldest son of the Honourable Henry Cooper, merchant, of this city. One of the fairest, happiest gatherings of this rising republic contributed to the felicities of this sacred union. Among the guests were his Excellency President James S. Payne and Lady Payne, the Honourable the Secretary of State and wife, the Honourable C. B. Dunbar, M.D., and wife, and H. J. G. Modderman, Acting Consul for the Netherlands. The early period of the evening was most agreeably spent; music and song, and the manifest care, forethought, and solicitude of the host and hostess for the perfect enjoyment and gratification of their guests, rendering everything delightful. The nuptial rites being ended, and followed by a sumptuous and more substantial repast than the preceding varied and delicious dainties during the evening, dancing, under the graceful leading of the bridegroom...

and bridal suite, succeeded, and was continued, with refreshing intervals throughout the lovely moonlight night, long after the youthful bride had departed to her new-made home, and the bright morning star, sparklingly pellucid in rapt serenity, bespoke the approach of day.—Advertisement."}, {'id': 5179, 'article_title': 'The Presidential Contest in Liberia', 'full_section_title': 'The Presidential Contest in Liberia', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-17', 'issue_date': '01_08_1885', 'content': 'The apprehensions which seem to prevail on the part of the ignorant in Liberia that England wants their country, are known to those who for political purposes foster these apprehensions to be absurd. The desire of England is really to assist the young Republic to stand up and take her place among the nations. But since now the British colony of Sierra Leone and the Republic of Liberia have become conterminous, it is not natural to suppose that England is prepared to look with complacency or even sympathy upon a next door neighbour whose backwardness—willful backwardness—interferes with the welfare of her possessions. But if Liberia will live up to her intelligence and the light she has—if she will make her laws more liberal as they relate to foreigners and foreign trade—if she will abandon her dog-in-the-manger policy, she may look for the sympathy and co-operation of Her Majesty's representatives on the coast. England has never hankered after sovereignty over West African territory; what she wants is trade. *The Times* not long since (September 15, 1884) said significantly: "It is not so much our interest that trade should be carried on under our flag as that trade *under whatever flag* should be free." We earnestly hope that Liberia may be able to put herself in accord with the spirit of progress for Africa, and work in harmony with and utilize the European and American agencies now coming to the coast. Meanwhile the Republican party need to be congratulated on the principles they have recently promulgated in the Republic, and so strenuously fought for. Good seed has been sown of which ere long the fruit will be seen.—*The Methodist Herald.*'}]
