[{'id': 445, 'article_title': 'LAGOS', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1864#article-9', 'issue_date': '23_09_1864', 'content': 'We are sorry to see, by new reports of deaths, that Lagos is still in an unhealthy state. An "ordinance to compel owners of swamp lands to fill up the same" having been confirmed in England, has now been promulgated, and it will no doubt lead to beneficial results. Another ordinance has been sanctioned in England, and issued in the colony. It is "to raise 600 additional Houssa armed police for the service of Lagos." These, with the preexisting ones, will form a *regiment.* We hope the revenue of Lagos will suffice for this and other services; but it is a large establishment for the finances of a place where a comparatively small trade is now being carried on. We hope it does not mean *military action in the interior,* as we do not think that the Abeokutan difficulties could be thus solved. No change has yet taken place as regards them, and we do not see anything to indicate that the long-hoped-for reopening of the roads and trade is about to take place. This is greatly to be deplored—but it seems difficult to find a remedy, as the struggle between the Egbas and Ibadans, far from languishing, seems to acquire fresh vigour (if the word vigour can be at all applied to such a war) day by day. Mr. Tickle, however, one of the Badagry merchants, has been wisely and pacifically sent up by Acting Governor Glover to the camp of the Egbas, in order if possible to arrange a meeting between his Excellency and the Egba authorities.

The Protectorate of Ikoradu has been abandoned.'}, {'id': 1212, 'article_title': 'Human Sacrifice Prevented at Ningo', 'full_section_title': 'Human Sacrifice Prevented at Ningo', 'last_edit_date': '10-25-1867', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1867#article-8', 'issue_date': '23_11_1867', 'content': "The whole of these persons were conducted the following day in safety to James Fort, Accra. The chiefs of every town from Pram Pram to Accra, as the troops passed through, came voluntarily and offered submission to the Government, so salutary was the effect of the Ningo affair on their minds.

It would be impossible to exaggerate the good that this business will bring about, and, indeed, has already brought about, in all the Coast towns from Accra to Addah. Nothing has been done like this since Sir William Winniett sacrificed his life in October, 1850, in his expedition to Addah.

Great credit is due to all concerned in this affair. Immense good has been effected by a judicious display of physical force without the shedding of a drop of blood. Credit is due to the Civil Commandant and Captain Ness for not hesitating to take the responsibility of dealing promptly with the Ningos without waiting for orders from Accra, as well as for the manner in which they dealt with the matter at Ningo; the firmness of Captain Ness at a critical moment prevented the shedding of blood, and at the same time conduced to the success of the expedition. An officer who at a similar crisis actually fled—I say fled, and mean to use the word as it is understood in England—from his post, obtained his promotion for his flight. This was not very long ago. Captain Ness may possibly be overlooked, as there was no blood shed and no running away; but his services on this occasion ought never to be forgotten by this Government.

Mr. Elliott's arrangements for the comfort of the troops were excellent. The men lived better than if they had been in barracks. Luxuries were provided for them at every place they came to. There was no confusion, no mixing ammunition with provisions; everything was in its place. The medical department was equally well cared for by Dr. Eaton. In fact, under a man like Ness things could not have gone wrong. The management of details not immediately connected with the military was ably conducted by Mr. Bolton, who was assisted by Mr. R. Bannerman. The Administrator has been lucky in having such men to carry out his orders. On the other hand, it must be admitted that unless they had been sure of his support they would not have acted as they did. Colonel Conran and Mr. Pine would have got no one to move a peg for them in this way. I think now that it will not be long before Mr. Usher becomes as convinced as I have always been that peace, in this part of the world at least, is easier brought about by a judicious use of armaments than by arguments. I do not wish to indulge in invidious observations, but I am of opinion

that had Captain Ness and his fifty men been sent to Aquamboe six months ago he would have effected a treaty very different from the Blackall peace, the good results of which would have been felt immediately, and have been lasting. — Yours truly,  
**An Old Correspondent.**"}, {'id': 1683, 'article_title': 'The War on the Bonny River', 'full_section_title': 'The War on the Bonny River', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1869#article-10', 'issue_date': '23_11_1869', 'content': "A great battle between Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja had terminated the native war at Bonny. The fight lasted nearly thirty-six hours, and the slaughter on both sides was immense. It ended in the total defeat of Ja Ja's troops, and the capture by Oko Jumbo of seventy guns of different calibre. Negotiations were going on between the rival chiefs, and at one time 1,000 puncheons of palm-oil were demanded from Ja Ja; subsequently the quantity was reduced to twenty, but it was generally believed, by the intervention of the traders, and the presence of one of Her Majesty's ships at Bonny, that amicable arrangements would be concluded between the Manilla Pepple people and the Ja Jas. The destruction of the town of Bonny was almost completed, one side of it being entirely swept away, whilst other parts are in a state of wreck. The guns, which ranged from 36lb. to 68lb., were fired at the extraordinary short range of 160 yards, with heavy charges of grape and canister, and the havoc was fearful. The bush was crowded with fugitives—men, women, and children—many being wounded in a shocking manner. Hundreds of dead and wounded were lying about the beach; whilst numbers of dead bodies, in clusters of three and four, were floating about in the creek. It was stated that Ja Ja had about 500 men killed outright, and about three or four times as many put hors de combat. When the Biafra left arrangements were being rapidly made for the reopening of trade."}, {'id': 1904, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST', 'last_edit_date': '08-23-1870', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_10_1870#article-4', 'issue_date': '24_10_1870', 'content': 'Mansu, August 23, 1870.

Sir,—I enclose you a few statements which I think the public ought to know. We are here ready to attack our Ashantah enemies. The Dutch soldiers have been forced out of the Apolonia Fort. Part of our force there have given the Axims, who attempted a fight against them, a severe flogging which they will never forget. More than one tribe of that neighbourhood have sent to swear allegiance with us, so as to save bloodshed. May God bring them to their senses, that we may not put an end to many lives on each side.—I am your obedient and humble servant,'}, {'id': 2772, 'article_title': "CAPTAIN LEES' MISSION TO ASHANTI.", 'full_section_title': "CAPTAIN LEES' MISSION TO ASHANTI.", 'last_edit_date': '08-31-1874', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_09_1874#article-5', 'issue_date': '30_09_1874', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—You will, I know, be anxious to learn how Captain Lees' mission to the Ashanti countries progressed and terminated; and I think you will be pleased with the results, so far as they have transpired. It is not easy to know exactly all that occurred, but I think you can rely on the following so far as it goes:

You will remember that the message of the King to the Governor-in-Chief was in the form of a deprecation of collision between himself and his late associate or tributary kings, and especially between himself and Juabin. He had been trying by all possible means to bring the Juabins to serve under him again, but they refused. He then sent threatening messages to them, whereupon they took up arms against him, and were joined by Quocofoo and Mampon.

On the arrival of Captain Lees, the King endeavoured to impress on him the importance of his power; but he was soon undeceived, as the homely truth was soon brought to him that he had none. He wanted to have all the chiefs again under his government; but he was told that the British Government is perfectly neutral in the matter; if the chiefs like to return, they may; but if not, they may remain as they are. He was very much annoyed and downcast at this decision, but there was no help for it. He was plainly told, should he go to war against Juabin, that Quocofoo, Mampon, and others would join them; and the result would be, that he would be dethroned and somebody else put in his place. After a good deal of palavering, he gave in, and Captain Lees, after much talk, got him to agree to the five following propositions:—

1. The separation and independence of Juabin.
2. That there must be general peace between all parties.
3. That all prisoners in the possession of each party should be delivered, so that those who wish to return may do so.
4. That roads to the interior be kept opened, and no party shall be molested whilst passing through for trade, &c.
5. That all old quarrels are to be buried, and not to be raked up again.

After the King had agreed to these, Captain Lees went to Juabin, saw the King and Chiefs, and then explained to them all the advantages they would obtain by this arrangement, which they finally agreed to accept. The King of Ashanti wanted them to come and eat fetish with him, or ratify the agreement in Kumasi; but the wily Juabins were too wide awake, and would not, as they said "Koffee Carry Carry has got very bad fetish." He, however, sent his messengers to the capital of Juabin, and the five propositions were ratified by the eating of fetish.'}, {'id': 2789, 'article_title': 'MURDER OF TWO FRENCH EXPLORERS IN AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'MURDER OF TWO FRENCH EXPLORERS IN AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_09_1874#article-22', 'issue_date': '30_09_1874', 'content': "The Geographical Society of Paris have received further details respecting the murder of M.M. Dournaux-Dopéré and Joubert by deserters of the Chamba tribe, which add little to what was already known. It would appear that, when about seven days' journey from Ghadamés, they were met by seven persons who declared they were perishing from hunger, and asked their hospitality. Their account seemed so satisfactory that, after their being furnished with food, they were admitted into the caravan, when suddenly, taking advantage of an unguarded moment, the new comers threw themselves upon M.M. Dupéré and Joubert, and their servant Ahmed-ben-Zerma, and murdered them. The Chambas then stripped them of their clothes and carried off all their property, with the exception of a few printed European books which they had left upon the ground. The account was brought back to Ghadamés by the camel-drivers—witnesses of the murder, who were spared by the assassins as neutrals. Had it been otherwise, the travellers not fallen victims to the Chambas, it is most probable they would never have reached the end of their journey, as a band of Tenaregg Huggars were also on their track, but turned back when they heard the Chambas had effected their purpose. The guide Nahécor-ben-Ettahur, who had arranged

their murder with the Chamba, had been sent to prison by the caimacan of Ghadamés previous to their departure, his bad faith having been discovered by the travellers. It appears that the caimacan of Ghadamés had entreated them to desist from their journey to Ghât. Notwithstanding this catastrophe, another exploration of the Sahara towards Timbuctoo is being organized by M. Largea, of Geneva.—*Academy.*"}, {'id': 3691, 'article_title': 'The Origin, Progress, and Temporary Settlement of the Awoonah Troubles', 'full_section_title': 'The Origin, Progress, and Temporary Settlement of the Awoonah Troubles', 'last_edit_date': '11-06-1878', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1879#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_01_1879', 'content': "On October 23rd, he sailed with a Captain of Messrs. Swanzy's, Mr. Laver, of the brig Alligator, to Abrovoe—a town out of the jurisdiction, and also situated as an inland town, being the source of all produce—to hunt. The inhabitants of this town are quite bush people, so the preceding Commandants never frequented the place. Some of the inhabitants were engaged in thatching a house; and the people taking it be a customer of theirs only coming to visit the place, went out in a flock (as is generally the case when Africans see a white man) to meet the boat; and the head man, with whom all traders generally put up, with a cutlass in hand with which he was working, first approached the boat, and, to his surprise, was fired at from the boat—it is said by Captain Ellis; the ball went through his breast, and in order to defend himself he tried to cut Captain Laver, who was nearest him; he held up his gun, and the man missed him, but seized and held the gun of Captain Laver in such a manner that the gun was turned against himself; whereupon the Captain fired at his throat, and he fell down. The Captain then took the cutlass from the man, and, it is said, began cutting him continuously till the man died. In the meanwhile the friends who came to see what was going on were fired at by Captain Ellis, and some were wounded very severely. After that the bystanders were fired at, and some were wounded. During this action the boat grounded. This shows that if the people had any malicious intention against them, they might easily have come against them and cut them in pieces; but, on the contrary, they left them alone. Captain Ellis returned with his company, and brought the report that some Awoonahs tried to defy him, whereupon he shot them like dogs. As soon as he arrived, he made his forces (Houssas) ready for fight, and gave orders that nobody should be allowed to go out after six p.m. In consequence of this, the splendid market which falls on every fourth day, and which was useful both to rich and poor, was stopped.

poor, was stopped; and no produce was to be got, as the people at the river-side were afraid to come for fear of being shot."}, {'id': 5236, 'article_title': 'Trade in the Gambia', 'full_section_title': 'Trade in the Gambia', 'last_edit_date': '10-13-1885', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-4', 'issue_date': '02_11_1885', 'content': "Colonel Stanley is fully alive to the danger and difficulties to which trade is exposed at the Gambia by reason of the constant civil wars and disturbances which take place along the banks of the river, and he is anxious to find some means of protecting it.

It is obviously impossible for Her Majesty's Government to undertake to put down the native wars and punish the marauding chiefs by means of military force, and Colonel Stanley is of opinion that a naval expedition would be likely to fail of success, and to have no lasting effect, as on the appearance of ships of war the chiefs would simply withdraw their forces a short distance into the interior, where they could be safe from any naval attack, and on the retirement of the vessels would return again to the river banks and renew their depredations with increased violence and hostility.

Colonel Stanley is, however, in correspondence with the Admiralty with the view of endeavouring to arrange that Her Majesty's ships on the West African station should pay more frequent visits to the Gambia, in order to show that a sufficient force is at hand if an opportunity of using it with effect should occur.

Colonel Stanley proposes now to send copies of your letters to the Governor of the West African Settlements, and desire him, so soon as he can properly leave Sierra Leone, to proceed to the Gambia and inquire into the matters complained of; to endeavour, if possible, to negotiate with Beram Ciesey, and the other chiefs, for the maintenance of peace and the neutrality of the river banks; and to report generally what steps he would recommend for the protection of trade.

As you are no doubt aware, Sir S. Rowe's extensive knowledge and experience of West African affairs, and his influence with the natives, has already enabled him to do much towards the re-establishment of peace and order, and the development of trade in the countries adjacent to Sierra Leone; and Colonel Stanley has every confidence that his skill and judgment will produce equally beneficial results at the Gambia.—I am, &c.,"}, {'id': 5500, 'article_title': 'THE EMIN BEY EXPEDITION', 'full_section_title': 'THE EMIN BEY EXPEDITION', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1887#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_03_1887', 'content': "Apart from this reason, there were other powerful arguments which might be brought. The expedition is non-military, its purpose is to save, to relieve distress, to carry comfort. Emin Pacha may be a good man, a brave officer, a gallant fellow, deserving of a strong effort of relief; but I decline to believe that his life would overbalance the lives of thousands of natives, and the devastation which an expedition strictly military would naturally cause. The expedition is a powerful caravan, armed with rifles for the purpose of insuring the safe conduct of the ammunition to Emin Pacha, and for the protection of the people during the retreat home. But it has means of purchasing the friendship of tribes and chiefs, of buying food and paying its way liberally. Because it has weapons of war and sufficient power to enforce supplies, the obligations which it has undertaken do not entitle it to rob or take by force anything from the poor natives of Africa, who are not responsible for the forlorn state of the Egyptians. But if the natives refuse to permit the peaceful passage of the expedition, and rush to the assault, then they must be resisted. To enable the expedition to effect the relief of Emin with the least harm, and to assure a certainty of success, the Congo route was selected.

Then, if we forced our way through territories subject to Uganda, Mwanga might retaliate by murdering the missionaries. The Congo route permits the expedition to approach within 360 miles of Lake Albert without disturbing any but small tribal chiefs. The Karagwe route is 290 miles from Uthungu to Lake Albert. No Europeans have travelled over any part of it but Col. J. A. Grant and myself. Col. Grant is a member of Committee of the Relief Fund.

The Masai route has 420 miles of unknown country between Kenia Mount and Faliko. Its dangers are unknown.

Let us compare the length of the various routes by days, assuming that an average of six miles could be made daily:—

- Congo route, 99 days' land journeys; Zanzibar to Congo, 20; Lower Congo, 3; Upper Congo, 35 (by steamer)—total, 157 days' voyage. Karagwe route, 156 days' land journey; Masai route, 154 days' land journey.

The above facts speak for themselves.

Emin Bey’s force is distributed among eight stations. The garrisons of the northernmost stations were discontented and mutinous at last accounts. They answered Emin’s advice to consolidate with reproaches. His suggestions that they should withdraw, via Zanzibar, were responded to by accusations that he intended to sell them as slaves. Junker cannot give an exact figure of the force itself.

I expect my men from Wady Halfa to be here this afternoon. They will accompany me to Suez. The Navarino is to arrive at Suez on Friday, when we will embark."}, {'id': 6347, 'article_title': 'THE ROYAL NIGER COMPANY.', 'full_section_title': 'THE ROYAL NIGER COMPANY.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1893#article-0', 'issue_date': '01_08_1893', 'content': 'The Thirteenth Ordinary General Meeting and an Extraordinary General Meeting of this Company were held on July 13, 1899, the Right Hon. Lord ABERDARE, P.C., G.C.B., the Governor of the Company, in the chair.

The SECRETARY (Mr. Henry Morley) having read the notice convening the Ordinary General Meeting,

And the Annual Report having been taken as read, Lord ABERDARE said: It has been our habit for some years to deal with the commercial aspects of the Company in the report issued with our balance-sheet, while in my annual speeches I have put before you such political matters as are of important and interesting character. I propose to follow this course to-day, and I need hardly remind you how completely dependent on each other are commerce and politics in regions so unsettled, barbarous and difficult of access, as the Niger Territories. With one notable exception on the Upper Benue, to which I shall refer later, the political situation since we last met has been satisfactory. The troubles which had broken out between certain natives of the delta and some British merchants were repressed by a very successful expedition, and the peace then established has not been again disturbed. You will also remember that not long before our last meeting, two members of our Council had returned from a special mission to the Territories, during which they had visited a Mohammedan Emir then engaged in hostilities with the Company. They reported a complete re-establishment of amicable relations and an apparent removal of all causes of serious differences in the future. But our envoys felt, and we all felt, that the sincerity of this Emir would be best proved...
**115**'}, {'id': 6740, 'article_title': 'Central African Exploration', 'full_section_title': 'Central African Exploration', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1896#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_05_1896', 'content': 'Dr. J. A. Moloney, formerly medical officer of the Stairs Expedition to Ratanga, has returned to England on the completion of his expedition to the hitherto unexplored portions of the Chartered Company's territories west of Lake Nyassa. Dr. Moloney left England last May, at the head of an expedition, including among its members Lieuts. Elwes and Biscoe, and several other Englishmen. The expedition proceeded direct to Bandawe, on the west shore of Lake Nyassa, north of Kota Kota, where a number of carriers and native soldiers were enlisted. Dr. Moloney did not find it necessary to fire a single shot during the whole of his journey.

The objects of the expedition were to locate certain territory in Northern Rhodesia lying between Lake Tanganyika and the Stevenson Road on the north, Portuguese East Africa on the south, the Nyassaland Protectorate on the east, and the Congo State on the west. This territory had never been explored, but had been visited by Dr. Livingstone, the late Mr. Joseph Thompson, and the present Acting Commissioner in British Central Africa. It is inhabited by people of Zulu origin, who have displaced the aborigines. After a stay of five months Dr. Moloney returned last January to Lake Nyassa, and returned to England a few weeks ago. In an interview with a representative of Reuter's agency, Dr. Moloney said: "Although the territories to the west of Nyassa are perfectly peaceful at present, there are certain political conditions that will have to be treated from a diplomatic standpoint. The territory visited by me is divided into two parts—Northern and Southern Angoniland. Although recent operations in Nyassaland have subjugated the Arab slave traders in the Protectorate, there are four chiefs in this territory who will have to be reckoned with in the future. These men are Mpseni, Chekusi, Chewire, and Ongonomo. Three of them exercise certain power within the Protectorate itself. When I left, Major Forbes, who
**69**

administers Northern Rhodesia, had not come into contact with these men. As a result of treaties concluded by me, white men can now travel through the country without fear of molestation. With the exception of a German trader, Herr Viese, who represented the Portuguese, no previous traveller has been able to remain in this country. Mr. Joseph Thompson, in visiting Mpseni, had to retreat after a few hours, and Mr. Alfred Sharpe only escaped with his life through Herr Viese's intercession. As a result of my negotiations I succeeded in placing under the British flag four big chiefs. Owing to Portuguese influence, Mpseni, although friendly, would not accept the British flag."'}]

[{'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have numerous treaties with the natives, beginning from 1826; they relate, in some instances, to cessions of territory, and always contain engagements for the protection of trade, the abolition of slavery, and the preservation of peace. They are not entered into by the natives without great consideration, and as they are rarely, if ever, broken, they are decidedly beneficial to the colony. Moreover, they afford us the plea for proffering our intervention when they show a disposition to quarrel amongst themselves, and in some recent instances our interference has been attended with very good results. The practice which has been long and successfully followed at Sierra Leone, of paying the chiefs small stipends to encourage them in observing these engagements, might advantageously be introduced at the Gambia.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.651, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Good Relations with Ashantee: How to Restore and Maintain them', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following suggestions on this important subject have been made by one long resident on the Gold Coast. Peace relations with Ashantee and a constantly open trade are of vital moment as regards revenue and the general well-being of the Protectorate, and we readily insert the following, as we should any other suggestions emanating from similar sources. We shall examine the practicability of this and other suggestions on another occasion:—

"It is only by constant and frequent communication with Ashantee and other barbarous tribes that we can hope to bring about that state of things that will redound to the honour of England, and I have often wondered why the chief of the executive here has not attempted some effective means for this end. I would suggest the following: Let a well-paid consular agent be stationed at Kumasi,* with Prince Ansah† as interpreter; let their salary be in keeping with England's dignity, and I imagine schools and other missionary work would then commence in earnest in Ashantee. But it would be necessary that the King should also be induced to send us a consul or agent, who ought to be well treated, and made acquainted with the refinements of European life. He should not be an ordinary chief or captain, but one of Ashantee's nobles, because there are many there. With this guarantee here, our Administrator could with every safety visit Ashantee, and display, in a dignified and graceful manner, the refined customs of Europe. The Africans are very imitative, and, depend upon it, good—real good—would be the result, such good as would outweigh 5,000l. per annum, if expended in the manner it ought to be. Let a trial be made for five years, and mark the result.—Yours truly,', 'last_edit_date': '1867-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1867#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.613, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Our Peace-making in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'For the last six or seven years the representatives of the British Government at Lagos have been engaged in mediating between belligerent tribes in the interior, which have been involved in a sort of guerilla warfare from time immemorial, and had been fighting pitched battles for the last ten years. At last the efforts made have been crowned with success. The contending factions were grouped into two opposing sides. On the one side were the Ibadans, a powerful tribe situated right in the centre of the region of the war, and, therefore, surrounded by enemies; and on the other was a confederation of tribes under the general name of the Ekitiparapos. Man-catching was the real object of the war, and herein lay the great difficulty in the way of mediation; for it was obvious that none of the man-catching tribes would surrender their main source of revenue without a struggle. However, with the aid of two educated natives, a treaty of peace was signed in July, 1886, and ratified in the following September.

The first circumstance which opened up a prospect of successful mediation was an intimation received by Administrator Moloney, at Lagos, of a quarrel between the King of the Sebus and his people, the former wanting to continue the war and the latter to end it. It was not till long afterwards that Sir Samuel Rowe felt he was justified in interfering. His first attempt was not encouraging, but ultimately the Kings of the Ekitiparapos confederacy, twenty-six in number, appealed to the Governor, stating their grievances against the Ibadans, and asking him to prevent their being supplied with ammunition from Lagos through the agency of an Ibadan there.

The answer came from Mr. Moloney, who had assumed the government of the colony, and he addressed it to all the belligerents, rating them soundly for continuing the war, and offering his services as mediator. The replies were favourable. An armistice was arranged, and conferences were held. Statements setting forth the case for each tribe separately were forwarded to the Governor. In one of them (from the commander of the Jebus) the following passage occurs: "Ile Ife is regarded by all our nation as the sacred spot from which we originated, and the Oni is respected as the father of all the Kings. This is why the Jebu King felt it his duty to reinstate the Ifes in the town. It was from Ile Ife that his father went to settle in the Jebu country. His father did not die, but he was converted into a rock, which could still be seen. Even the English King can be shown the spot at Ile Ife from whence his ancestors went out. So we are fighting not only in the interest of our King, but also of the crowned heads in the whole world."', 'last_edit_date': '1887-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1887#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.614, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE RECENT DISTURBANCES AT NOKKI', 'section_title': '', 'content': "It appears a difference had arisen between the trading establishments of the Lower Congo and the inhabitants of the villages situated about three and a half hours' walking distance from Nokki. A caravan sent into the interior by the Dutch establishment, Afrikaansche Handels-Vermootschap, was pillaged, and had two men killed. In consequence of this aggression, all the European establishments declared war against the natives of these villages. A body of 150 armed negroes, recruited among the *personnel* of the Dutch, French, and Portuguese factories, and commanded by fifteen Europeans, went to the hostile villages to inflict chastisement. The natives yielded at first, but having been gradually reinforced by new combatants, they afterwards offered a vigorous resistance. The chief of a body of Krooboys having been wounded, his men, to the number, of eighty-four, took to flight. The Europeans, numbering seventy combatants, could not sustain the onset of the united forces of the natives, and were obliged to retreat hastily. During the retreat, the agent of a French house, M. Barbier, was killed, and three Europeans were wounded. The natives pursued the Europeans as far as Nokki, and disposed themselves to attack simultaneously that point and the point of Wang-Wang. Owing to this danger, M. Gresshoff, principal agent of the Afrikaansche Handels-Vermootschap, addressed a pressing demand for succour to Major Parminter. His letter arrived at Vivi at nightfall, and Major Parminter immediately assembled the Houssas at his disposal and sent them to the relief of the threatened establishments. The steamers of the Association, Belgique and Espérance, were, unfortunately, at this moment down the river. The small troop had, therefore, to embark in native boats, and they arrived at Nokki after a very perilous voyage, accomplished on a river whose current is known to be of extreme violence. On reaching Nokki, arrangements were made to secure the safety of the European establishments. Mr. Shaw, who commanded the relief party, had been ordered by his chief to give every assistance to the Europeans in case of an attack by the natives. It had been especially enjoined on him not to resort to force before having tried to enter into negotiations with the natives, and used every effort in conformity with the principles of the Association in order to prevent the shedding of blood. He was to hoist the flag of the Association, so that the natives could perceive that they now had to do with it. The sight of the flag produced on the assailants the moral effect which the Chief of Vivi expected from it. The natives abstained from a new attack. Landing on the following day at Nokki, Mr. Parminter found there the Association's steamer Belgique, which had arrived with reinforcements from Bonna. Mr. Parminter returned to his post at Vivi, leaving at the threatened point a detachment of Houssas, under the orders of one of his agents, in the hope that their presence would prevent a renewal of hostilities. He offered at the same time hospitality and protection at Vivi to the English missionaries at Under Hill, and also to Mrs. Crudgington, in case they did not think themselves safe at their station. He also authorized one of the agents of the Association to place himself at the disposal of the house Daumas-Béraud of Paris until it could replace M. Barbier. Before leaving Nokki, Mr. Parminter received the thanks and congratulations of the European agents, who begged to express their gratitude to the Committee for the prompt and efficacious help which they had received in a moment of peril. Mr. Parminter had offered the Europeans to open, in their name, negotiations with the natives in order to bring about the cessation of hostilities and the re-establishment of peace, but the excitement caused by the late events, and especially by the death of M. Barbier, was still too great for his offer to be accepted. Thanks to the measures taken by Mr. Parminter, tranquillity was not again disturbed; but on February 17 a post which had neglected on that day to hoist the flag of the Association was taken for a post belonging to the factories, and attacked by the natives. In this attack a Zanzibarite was killed and another wounded. When the packet left, the natives had again threatened the factories. The Sagittaire was on the way to Nokki, followed by two small Portuguese men-of-war. From the foregoing, it follows undoubtedly that the International Association has gained considerable influence in the country, and, according to its promises, this influence is used in the interests of the cause which the Association professes to serve.", 'last_edit_date': '1884-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1884#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.61, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ENGLISH CIVILISATION IN THE NIGER REGION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"And what impression has your tour made?"—"We have returned well satisfied with the work of administration and also with the commercial development which is going on. The trade in forest products is growing, and the plantations which have been started at Abutchi, Nkissi, and other places for the purpose of instructing the natives in the cultivation of coffee, cocoa, and other products hitherto unknown in these regions are making satisfactory progress. Although tribal wars are still frequent among the pagans, they are greatly diminished in number and intensity, and disputes are so frequently referred to the Company's district courts for decision as to demand a much larger staff than the present petty revenue of the Company can afford. I was especially struck with the great advance that has taken place of late years in the intelligence of the natives who have come in contact with Europeans. Members of tribes formerly savages and cannibals are now competent to act as domestic servants, interpreters, pilots, engineers, and even captains of steamers. No doubt they retain many of their barbarous habits, as the practices of generations are not changed in a day."

"Has slave-raiding been checked to any extent?"—"The raiding of the Mohammedan slave-dealers into the pagan regions under our jurisdiction has undoubtedly been checked by means of the careful disposition of our troops along the Benue river. The number of troops set apart for this work has had to be considerably augmented, and we hope that this will lead to a large development in trade and in the cultivation of the land in regions which have hitherto been depopulated by the slave-raiders."

"Does this active interference with the slave trade not raise up enemies?"—"Notwithstanding these operations, the relations with the Mohammedan Emirs continue on the whole friendly, the principal exception being the Emir of Muri, a province to the north of the Upper Benue. Strong pressure has been brought to bear upon him by the Sultan of Sokoto, who is an ally of the Company, and with whom we have a treaty, to bring the Emir to a more pacific frame of mind. There is nothing in this hostility to cause the slightest anxiety, as the Company are perfectly able to cope with any force the Emir of Muri can bring against them. In a vast country split up into a great many separate States and tribes it is impossible to expect that perfect peace should reign, but on the whole the condition of affairs is decidedly pacific and encouraging."', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.616, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In New Calabar River, in the Niger delta—a native river—war having broken out, our Consul, who is a smart, clever man, intervened at once, and as one side declined to cease fighting, he ordered a gunboat to the place to protect the trade. But in this, a British river, our property may be looted or burnt, our servants, so long as they were not born in a British settlement, may be slaughtered, while aid or protection we have none. Perhaps, on the principle of killing a director on an English railway, if the Marabouts of Badibboo were to beat or shoot our Administrator, the Government would wake up, and show some of their boasted "spirited foreign policy."—Yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1879-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1879#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.635, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE WELFARE OF THE AFRICAN RACES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**Sir R. Fowler** had pleasure in supporting the resolution, because he felt their thanks were due to the King of the Belgians for the interest he had taken in all African questions. The exertions of his Majesty had been continued and, if possible, increased, and it was a good augury of the cause they had at heart that one who was so worthy to occupy the position should preside over the Conference at Brussels.

The resolution was then put and carried unanimously.

**Mr. W. S. Caine** moved the following resolution: "That in the opinion of this meeting it is essential to the success of the work aimed at by the Conference that effective steps be taken for the removal of two prominent causes of injury to native races in Africa—the one the indiscriminate supply to them of European arms and other munitions of war, by which internecine strife is encouraged, and the weaker tribes are made victims of the stronger; the other, the traffic in alcoholic liquors, by which the people are grievously degraded, exposed to increased risks of conquest and enslavement, and rendered incapable of receiving the benefits of legitimate commerce and civilisation." He said that this resolution was a proper sequel to the one the meeting had just agreed to. One of the new kings of Africa had that day told them plainly that the South African Company intended to conduct its operations on the basis of the resolution, and he had read clauses in the charter referring to the abolition of the slave trade and the trade in alcohol, and that the trade in spirituous liquors would be regulated. He trusted that the result of the meeting might be to awaken the public conscience, and that, societies and churches...

might speak out and give expression to their opinions in the shape of memorials to be presented to the Brussels Conference.

Mr. A. M'ARTHUR, seconded the motion.

Commander CAMERON, R.N., remarked that the question of the importation of arms into Africa was one of the greatest importance. He knew how necessary it was to prevent arms and ammunition from being poured wholesale into Africa. The people of England should understand of what supreme importance it was that the importation of arms into Africa should be kept within the narrowest possible limits.

The resolution was agreed to unanimously.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.612, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Progress on the West African Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The African rivers situate in the Bight of Benin, commonly known as the Oil Rivers, have been placed under the protectorate of Great Britain. The protectorate, announced at Bonny, in December last, by Admiral Sir Walter Hunt Grubb, extends from the right bank of Benin river to the Rio del Rey, thus including Brass, New and Old Calabar, Bonny, Opobo, and other important trading stations.

Two series of considerations, the internal and external, have combined to render action imperative, and a retrospective view may not be uninstructive. Since the abolition of the export of slaves, these localities have been the sites of trading stations, palm oil being the chief article of export. The traders have been, with few exceptions, British, and the capitalists mostly Liverpool merchants. The natives allowed trading hulks to be anchored and commerce conducted on payment of fixed sums, known as "comey." Bonny, Brass, and Old Calabar are among the oldest of these trading ports, the native chiefs being also the native traders. They possessed numerous slaves who were sent with merchandise to the interior markets to collect oil, which was brought to the stations and sold to the whites. Among the Bonny chiefs was the father of Ja Ja, late King of Opobo; his son was brought up to the management of the business, and on his father's death he succeeded to his position. Of his enemies the most powerful was Oko Jumbo, who lost no opportunity to humiliate him. The Europeans could only let matters take their course; they regretted constant fighting of Oko Jumbo and Ja Ja, but the relations between the Europeans and natives being strictly commercial, nothing could be done. Suffering reverses, Ja Ja was forced to fly with the remnant of his people after great slaughter at the hands of Oko Jumbo. He collected his scattered family, dependants, and slaves, and made his escape to the Opobo river. There Ja Ja found a place for his town, and established himself as King of Opobo.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.612, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'COPY OF THE REPORT OF COL. ORD, THE COMMISSIONER APPOINTED TO INQUIRE INTO THE CONDITION OF THE BRITISH SETTLEMENTS ON THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It will be considered presently whether larger reductions cannot be effected in the cost for military establishments without endangering the security of the settlements, and with increased efficiency to their administration.

Admitting that there may have been errors in the administration of these settlements, that their finances may not have been always carefully managed, and that differences or collisions with the natives have occurred which greater forethought or judgment might perhaps have in some instances prevented, it cannot be denied that, from their circumstances and position, they are exposed to risks and embarrassments from which most other colonies are free, and that whenever settlements are brought into contact with warlike and lawless savages, such complications as have occurred on the West Coast are by no means unfrequent, and are generally productive of financial and other difficulties.

The possibility of introducing improvements into their administration will, however, presently form a subject of consideration.

The suggestion that the benefits accruing from the settlements would be as readily obtained were they abolished, or, at least, made trading posts with a consul, is supposed to be supported by the fact that the oil rivers, as the district is termed in which the Benin, Nun, Calabar, and Bonny Rivers are situated, have a trade in palm oil exceeding that of the settlements, and yet that it is sustained without any aid or interference from Government.

This statement is perfectly correct, except as regards the non-interference of the Government, the Commodore being compelled at times to exercise all the authority which the power of the squadron gives him to maintain order in these rivers, which are said to be occasionally the scene of great irregularities.

It must, however, be borne in mind that the district in question is most prolific in palm-oil trees, and that ready access is obtainable to it through its numerous rivers; thus favourably situated, Europeans had every opportunity of making the natives aware of the value of the produce that lay around them, and of inducing them to turn their attention to its collection, whilst the facilities which were afforded the trade were such as are not to be found in any other part of Africa.

Urged by these considerations, the chiefs were soon led to see that it was more advantageous to employ their slaves in the manufacture of palm oil than to sell them; and it is easy to understand how, under these circumstances, no Government aid should have been required to create the large trade that now exists, and by its agency has abolished the former traffic in slaves.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-06-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FIGHTING IN CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A brilliant feat of arms has just been accomplished in Central Africa by a small British force, acting against a powerful army of Native chiefs and Arab slavedealers. The scene of the conflict is to the west of Lake Nyassa, in the country known as Angoniland, within the British Central African Protectorate; and a confederacy of slave-dealing chiefs seems to have been formed, with King Mwasigungu at its head, whose object was to dispute the right of the British to interfere with their man-hunting expeditions. Nobody can impute a shadow of bloodguiltiness in this matter to our representatives. Every effort appears to have been made by our Consul-General to come to terms with the barbarous potentate; but Mwasigungu rejected all offers, and actually declared war. No doubt he felt confident of beating the small force of Sikhs and Natives, who could be brought against him, and, as far as numerical superiority went, his confidence was not misplaced. In the actual conflict, Lieut. Alston and Captain Stewart, who commanded the Sikh contingent, had only 150 men under them, to which must be added a body of five thousand Natives. This little army marched into the country of the slave-dealers, and in three battles succeeded in utterly routing King Mwasigungu and the other chiefs, although they had a force of twenty thousand fighters. The danger of the enterprise can be gauged from the fact that two strong stockades had to be taken by assault, and Lieut. Alston is mentioned as having gallantly led the storming parties. Fifty towns were captured by the victorious British troops, and 600 prisoners, including 14 chiefs, fell into their hands. One of the latter, a notorious character, with the stain of past murders on his soul, was taken to the shores of Lake Nyassa, and there tried, condemned, and executed. The loss in the slavedealers' army was great, while six of the Sikhs seem to have fallen on our side. The capture of ninety guns, and the re-opening of the trade routes to the Luapula river, are not the greatest advantages to be derived from this achievement. The prestige of the Arab slave-dealers will have received a blow in all the region between the Portuguese border and the Loangwa; while the ability of the British to make their Protectorate a reality will be forcibly impressed on the Native mind. Not only has the capital of the presumptuous monarch been captured, but a fort has been built there and garrisoned by Protectorate troops, so that there will be a standing pledge and symbol of our authority in the heart of the country. Thus gradually the tide of civilisation sweeps over the darkest places of the Dark Continent, and not for the first or the last time has British daring and enterprise brought succour to the slave. If the process of "ransoming the African" has to be effected by violent means, then it is satisfactory to find that a force under the British flag is capable of meeting four times its number of Arabs, and putting them to rout. In a victory of this description there is much to be proud of and nothing to regret, for it is a triumph of justice and mercy over base greed and cruelty.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1896#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.607, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AN INTERVIEW WITH MR. H. M. STANLEY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"There would constantly be an immense quantity of goods going up country by rail. At present, on the Upper Congo, Europeans have to content themselves with living in wattled huts or mud forts, roofed over with straw and grass, and there is, of course, great danger from fire. By means of the railway the State could at once transport about a dozen iron stations; and there would soon be erected houses, churches, and schools, all of iron. Then the native chiefs, seeing what the Europeans were doing, would build iron houses, and would likewise require iron warehouses for their goods. The Chief of Kintamo, for instance, already keeps all his goods in iron boxes; while the Chiefs of Old Calabar live in iron houses which have cost from £1,000 to £3,500 each. Then, again, there would be many steamers to be transported in sections, to be put together on the upper side of the cataracts. On the Upper Congo there are at present only seven steamers, mostly steam launches, but to carry on the enormous trade of the 7,000 miles of navigable waterway of the Upper Congo, large and swift steamers will be required, capable of stowing cargo and carrying passengers in comfort. Again, there would be a large trade in timber, and saw-mills would be required to cut it up, which mills would have to be taken up country by railway. Enormous quantities of powder and large numbers of flint-lock guns would also be in demand. All this is without counting the almost limitless trade to be done in cloth goods. I should say that within a reasonable number of years after the making of the railway there would be a trade of about £10,000,000 annually with the natives of the Upper Congo—all in barter."

Pausing here, Mr. Stanley went on to say that there was a sentimental side to the whole question which was worthy of reflection. "We have been enabled," he continued, "with our own modest enterprise to secure something like 1,000 carriers a month to serve us in a country that, when I began work there, absolutely refused to have anything to do with us. Already we have some 400 native soldiers—all of which proves that the natives are friendly and willing to lend their services to the white man for his purposes. When the State can better afford it—which will be not long after the railway is finished—it will be able to enlist 3,000 or 4,000 native soldiers for the protection of the country against the slave-traders. Those stations which are to-day so modest and unoffending, and dare not take arms in their hands against the organized slave-traders, will, in a few months only after the opening of the railway, be in a position to take the offensive and absolutely prevent them from ever setting foot in the Congo State."

"That indeed would be worth working for," I remarked.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1886#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.608, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Policy of Non-Intervention in Western Africa: Its Mischievous Tendency on the Good Government of the Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'I have been long studying the character of the Marabouts of this river, and in my humble opinion the only way to live in peace and amity with them is to deal with them as the French do. When they are arrogant and very offensive give them a jolly good thrashing, and then afterwards shake hands with them, and say, "Now let us be good friends;" they will respect you the more. Let it be well understood that this will always be our course with them, and they will keep quiet, and trade will prosper.', 'last_edit_date': '1867-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1867#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.606, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Royal Niger Company Chartered and Limited', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Inducements for the best men to serve in Africa, but they contribute from their national exchequers towards the creation and initial development of their possessions, sums large in comparison with our petty revenues drawn entirely from local taxation. A striking example is that of the Congo Free State, which, in addition to the magnificent endowment of King Leopold, is subsidised to the extent of £80,000 a year by the Belgian Government. Great Britain, on the other hand, has never contributed a shilling to aid us in our work of exploration, civilisation and extirpation of the slave trade. It would be idle to complain, even if we were disposed to do so, of being thus left entirely to our own resources, and it may be that in the long run we shall profit more from the energy evoked and the liberty fostered by independence of State subsidies and State interference. But it is an indisputable fact that commerce on the Niger has suffered heavily during the last three years from the pecuniary encouragement given to our foreign neighbours. No appreciable effect is indeed produced in respect of those articles of African produce such as gum, kernels, oil and rubber, which are not suited for land carriage over long distances; but in respect of one valuable product—viz., ivory, which is carried on the backs of slaves for immense distances at a small cost, these subsidies, which practically amount to bonuses to the local merchants, have unquestionably diverted a considerable value from the Niger markets to those of more favoured regions, and have thus diminished your annual dividends to the extent of at least 4 per cent. It is not easy to see how this result has benefited the taxpayers of the European States which pay these bonuses out of their home exchequers; but it has undoubtedly enriched the merchants of various nationalities trading in their African possessions at the expense of commerce in unsubsidised British possessions where the whole cost of administration and development has to be met by taxation on trade. Passing from these considerations of our external relations to our neighbours, I will say a few words on our own internal condition, that is on the progress of settlement within our present sphere of operations. You may perhaps remember that at our meeting two years ago I dwelt at considerable length on the great difficulties with which we have had to contend, apart from those arising from the unhealthiness of the climate and from the intermittent residence and consequent want of continuity in our staff in Africa. I pointed out that "we have to deal with 800 tribes who have been for countless generations plunged in idle barbarism, whose sole idea of wealth has been the holding of slaves, and whose main occupation in life has been to acquire such slaves by intertribal war or kidnapping." I am glad to be able to tell you that year by year there has been a steady growth of the whole, some influence and power of the Company—a growth necessarily slow and incomplete, but more rapid than we had ventured to anticipate. The missionaries in the Lower Niger have borne witness to the remarkable progress of peace and security under our rule. You must not understand me as saying that there is not still in those regions a vast amount of gross barbarism and uncurbed ferocity; but only that these have been mitigated and even in some places abated to a degree which more than justifies our presence there as the ruling power. Having achieved such striking success as far up the Niger as Lokoja, we have thought the time ripe for taking similar measures in the Pagan countries to the south of the Lower Benue; where, during the few years since we first established our stations, and probably for many years previously, incalculable miseries have been inflicted on the natives by slave hunters from the North and East. It is an inevitable consequence of these raids that their operations expand year by year in a wider circle, as belt after belt of country is devastated and depopulated, leaving no further prey for the slave hunters; so that tribes whom we had already commenced to train to peaceful commerce and whom we were teaching to utilise the natural resources of that fertile region, have disappeared, most of their members having been either killed or captured as slaves, while the more fortunate are hiding amongst the forests and rocks in hopes of escaping the fate of their companions. The region of which I am speaking is at present one of the principal hunting grounds for supplying the enormous and apparently insatiable demand for slaves in the Central Soudan and even as far as Morocco. You will at once understand that if we longer delayed taking the necessary remedial measures all hope of developing those fertile and once populous regions must be abandoned. We are therefore impelled by interest, as well as the ordinary feelings of humanity, to act decisively at this, the earliest practicable moment, and to afford these pagan populations— with whom we have made treaties—efficient protection to life, freedom, and property. This measure has demanded an increase to our small army and consequently additional expenditure, which must temporarily be met by increased taxation.
